For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles.     "output": "Thought: \nStep 1: Brainstorm 3 possible Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to link \u201cchiral light\u2013matter interaction\u201d and \u201cquantum photonics\u201d with quantum networks (no plain state generation):\n  a) A unidirectional (chiral) multi\u2010hop teleportation chain: use directional (one\u2010way) couplers to implement successive entanglement\u2010swapping\u2013based teleportation from node A to B to C to D, demonstrating a chiral quantum repeater. Modularly extendable to N hops.\n  b) A cyclic entanglement\u2010swapping ring across three (or four) nodes using chiral couplers: generate Bell pairs on each edge of a ring, perform Bell measurements at each vertex to \u201cswap\u201d entanglement around the loop in a directional fashion, exploring topological aspects of chiral networks.\n  c) A post\u2010selected, chiral \u201cquantum router\u201d that conditionally swaps two photonic qubits between two output ports based on the path\u2010encoded control qubit, implemented by directional beam\u2010splitter network\u2014i.e. a heralded CSWAP in a chiral geometry.\nStep 2: Quick novelty/obstacle check:\n  a) Multi\u2010hop teleportation: extends two\u2010node swapping to N\u2010node directional chain\u2014novel in ring/examples. No cavities; uses removed_connections to enforce one\u2010way links. Feasible for Pytheus.\n  b) Entanglement\u2010swapping ring: also new but more complex to specify target state (it ends up GHZ\u2010like if post\u2010selected).\n  c) Chiral Fredkin/router: interesting but edges toward quantum computing gates; risk of being flagged as state generation/gate synthesis.\nStep 3: Choose (a) multi\u2010hop teleportation chain\u2014clean network generalization, chiral enforced by removed_connections, directly shows chiral photonic routing advantages, expandable to arbitrary length.\nStep 4: This idea is novel because it demonstrates for the first time a post\u2010selected, purely linear\u2010optic, entanglement\u2010swapping\u2013based teleportation over a unidirectional (chiral) chain of more than two hops. It introduces a family of N\u2010hop chiral quantum repeaters implementable in free\u2010space or integrated photonics, with resource\u2010scaling advantages from directed couplings.\nStep 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because it only requires abstract Bell\u2010pair sources and single\u2010photon input, linear optics, photodetection, and \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to enforce one\u2010way (chiral) links\u2014no cavities, no feedback, no hybrid entanglement, no state generation target, just a targeted two\u2010dimensional teleportation channel \u201c|0>\u2192|0> and |1>\u2192|1>\u201d across four nodes. \nAction: final answer\nAction Input: \nHere is a proposal for Pytheus to design a \u201cchiral, multi\u2010hop teleportation chain\u201d that implements directional entanglement swapping (i.e. a chiral quantum repeater) between four nodes A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to teleport an unknown qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 from node A to node D by performing sequential entanglement\u2010swapping steps at intermediate nodes B and C, using only probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, single\u2010photon sources, linear optics, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. Chiral (unidirectional) coupling is enforced by forbidding any Bell\u2010pair source from connecting \u201cupstream\u201d to \u201cdownstream\u201d backwards (i.e. once a photon leaves A toward B it cannot return), mimicking spin\u2010momentum\u2010locking waveguides in an abstract way. This network can be generalized to N hops, illustrating how chiral couplers reduce resource overhead for long\u2010distance teleportation.\n\nVisualization:\n  - Single\u2010photon source at A emits the data qubit into the network.  \n  - Three Bell\u2010pair sources create pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D (each pair source probabilistic).  \n  - At node B: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the incoming data photon from A and one photon of the AB pair \u2192 swaps entanglement to B\u2013C link.  \n  - At node C: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the swapped photon from B\u2013C and one photon of the C\u2013D pair \u2192 final entanglement between A data and D.  \n  - After post\u2010selection, the output qubit emerges at D with the state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9, completing a two\u2010dimensional teleportation channel \u22230\u27e9\u2192\u22230\u27e9, \u22231\u27e9\u2192\u22231\u27e9.\n  - No direct source\u2010detector connections backward along the chain, enforced by removed_connections to encode chirality.\n\nConfig Template for Pytheus:\n{'description': 'Chiral 3\u2010hop teleportation chain A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D',\n 'foldername': 'chiral_3hop_teleport',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,    # loosened threshold for post\u2010selection\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',   # count\u2010rate overlap with ideal teleportation channel\n 'num_anc': 4,        # ancilla detectors for two Bell measurements (2 each)\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 20,\n 'target_quantum': ['00','11'],  # ideal identity channel on logical qubit A\u2192D\n 'single_emitters': [0],         # node 0 = A data photon\n 'amplitudes': [],\n 'tries_per_edge': 5,\n 'removed_connections': [\n     # forbid direct A\u2192C, A\u2192D, B\u2192D sources\n     [0,2],[0,3],[1,3]\n ],\n 'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNodes indexing:\n 0 = data photon source at A  \n 1,2,3 = detectors at B (post\u2010Bell measurement), C (post\u2010Bell measurement), D (output)  \n Ancillary detectors correspond to the other two outputs of each Bell\u2010measurement beam\u2010splitter.\n\nThis design can be extended to N hops simply by adding more Bell\u2010pair sources, more \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to enforce one\u2010way propagation, and extra measurement nodes. The Expert can hand off this abstract target to Pytheus, recover a linear\u2010optics circuit, and write up the first demonstration of a purely chiral, multi\u2010hop entanglement\u2010swapping teleportation network."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable Integrated Three-Photon GHZ-Basis Analyzer on Pytheus\n\nAbstract: We implement the target Pytheus-configurable three-photon GHZ-basis analyzer by injecting three unknown photonic qubits and an ancilla Bell pair into a fixed mesh of 50:50 beam splitters augmented with three on-chip electro-optic phase shifters and heralding detectors, thereby unambiguously mapping any incoming triple onto one of the four GHZ basis states. By reprogramming only the EOM voltages\u2014while leaving the linear-optical network unchanged\u2014the same device can project onto the W basis or any rotated three-qubit entangled basis, opening new avenues for adaptive entanglement swapping, secret sharing, and fundamental tests of nonlocality.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement Swapping of 2\u00d72 Toric-Code Logical Qubits via Linear Optics\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate entanglement swapping between two distant logical qubits, each encoded in a minimal 2\u00d72 toric-code patch of four photons at nodes A and D, by performing a post-selected logical Bell measurement on intermediate patches B and C using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, passive linear optics, and ancilla detection. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a proposal for Pytheus to design a \u201cchiral, multi\u2010hop teleportation chain\u201d that implements directional entanglement swapping (i.e. a chiral quantum repeater) between four nodes A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to teleport an unknown qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 from node A to node D by performing sequential entanglement\u2010swapping steps at intermediate nodes B and C, using only probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, single\u2010photon sources, linear optics, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. Chiral (unidirectional) coupling is enforced by forbidding any Bell\u2010pair source from connecting \u201cupstream\u201d to \u201cdownstream\u201d backwards (i.e. once a photon leaves A toward B it cannot return), mimicking spin\u2010momentum\u2010locking waveguides in an abstract way. This network can be generalized to N hops, illustrating how chiral couplers reduce resource overhead for long\u2010distance teleportation.\n\nVisualization:\n  - Single\u2010photon source at A emits the data qubit into the network.  \n  - Three Bell\u2010pair sources create pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D (each pair source probabilistic).  \n  - At node B: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the incoming data photon from A and one photon of the AB pair \u2192 swaps entanglement to B\u2013C link.  \n  - At node C: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the swapped photon from B\u2013C and one photon of the C\u2013D pair \u2192 final entanglement between A data and D.  \n  - After post\u2010selection, the output qubit emerges at D with the state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9, completing a two\u2010dimensional teleportation channel \u22230\u27e9\u2192\u22230\u27e9, \u22231\u27e9\u2192\u22231\u27e9.\n  - No direct source\u2010detector connections backward along the chain, enforced by removed_connections to encode chirality.\n\nConfig Template for Pytheus:\n{'description': 'Chiral 3\u2010hop teleportation chain A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D',\n 'foldername': 'chiral_3hop_teleport',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,    # loosened threshold for post\u2010selection\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',   # count\u2010rate overlap with ideal teleportation channel\n 'num_anc': 4,        # ancilla detectors for two Bell measurements (2 each)\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 20,\n 'target_quantum': ['00','11'],  # ideal identity channel on logical qubit A\u2192D\n 'single_emitters': [0],         # node 0 = A data photon\n 'amplitudes': [],\n 'tries_per_edge': 5,\n 'removed_connections': [\n     # forbid direct A\u2192C, A\u2192D, B\u2192D sources\n     [0,2],[0,3],[1,3]\n ],\n 'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNodes indexing:\n 0 = data photon source at A  \n 1,2,3 = detectors at B (post\u2010Bell measurement), C (post\u2010Bell measurement), D (output)  \n Ancillary detectors correspond to the other two outputs of each Bell\u2010measurement beam\u2010splitter.\n\nThis design can be extended to N hops simply by adding more Bell\u2010pair sources, more \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to enforce one\u2010way propagation, and extra measurement nodes. The Expert can hand off this abstract target to Pytheus, recover a linear\u2010optics circuit, and write up the first demonstration of a purely chiral, multi\u2010hop entanglement\u2010swapping teleportation network.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: This \u201cchiral multi\u2010hop teleportation chain\u201d is just the textbook sequential entanglement\u2010swapping repeater extended with a removed_connections trick to enforce one\u2010way links. It offers no new Bell\u2010measurement primitive or exotic causality superposition beyond standard multi\u2010link swapping (see, e.g., basic two\u2010link entanglement swapping, temporal\u2010mode multiplexing, flux\u2010controlled chiral teleportation routing). It therefore lacks the novelty threshold for a PRL\u2010worthy target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The proposal is merely a straightforward N\u2010hop extension of standard entanglement swapping with forbidden backward links (removed_connections); it adds no new measurement tool, channel superposition, or non\u2010trivial causal/coherence effect. To be novel, you must introduce a genuinely new primitive (e.g. coherent superposition of swap orders, programmable non-unitary supermaps, higher-dimensional network metrics) rather than enforcing directionality by graph constraints."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. Modularly extendable to N hops.\n  b) A cyclic entanglement\u2010swapping ring across three (or four) nodes using chiral couplers: generate Bell pairs on each edge of a ring, perform Bell measurements at each vertex to \u201cswap\u201d entanglement around the loop in a directional fashion, exploring topological aspects of chiral networks.\n  c) A post\u2010selected, chiral \u201cquantum router\u201d that conditionally swaps two photonic qubits between two output ports based on the path\u2010encoded control qubit, implemented by directional beam\u2010splitter network\u2014i.e. a heralded CSWAP in a chiral geometry.\nStep 2: Quick novelty/obstacle check:\n  a) Multi\u2010hop teleportation: extends two\u2010node swapping to N\u2010node directional chain\u2014novel in ring/examples. Chiral (unidirectional) coupling is enforced by forbidding any Bell\u2010pair source from connecting \u201cupstream\u201d to \u201cdownstream\u201d backwards (i.e. once a photon leaves A toward B it cannot return), mimicking spin\u2010momentum\u2010locking waveguides in an abstract way. This network can be generalized to N hops, illustrating how chiral couplers reduce resource overhead for long\u2010distance teleportation.\n\nVisualization:\n  - Single\u2010photon source at A emits the data qubit into the network.  \n  - Three Bell\u2010pair sources create pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D (each pair source probabilistic).  \n  - At node B: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the incoming data photon from A and one photon of the AB pair \u2192 swaps entanglement to B\u2013C link.  \n  - At node C: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the swapped photon from B\u2013C and one photon of the C\u2013D pair \u2192 final entanglement between A data and D.  \n  - After post\u2010selection, the output qubit emerges at D with the state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9, completing a two\u2010dimensional teleportation channel \u22230\u27e9\u2192\u22230\u27e9, \u22231\u27e9\u2192\u22231\u27e9.\n  - No direct source\u2010detector connections backward along the chain, enforced by removed_connections to encode chirality.\n\nConfig Template for Pytheus:\n{'description': 'Chiral 3\u2010hop teleportation chain A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D',\n 'foldername': 'chiral_3hop_teleport',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,    # loosened threshold for post\u2010selection\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',   # count\u2010rate overlap with ideal teleportation channel\n 'num_anc': 4,        # ancilla detectors for two Bell measurements (2 each)\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 20,\n 'target_quantum': ['00','11'],  # ideal identity channel on logical qubit A\u2192D\n 'single_emitters': [0],         # node 0 = A data photon\n 'amplitudes': [],\n 'tries_per_edge': 5,\n 'removed_connections': [\n     # forbid direct A\u2192C, A\u2192D, B\u2192D sources\n     [0,2],[0,3],[1,3]\n ],\n 'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNodes indexing:\n 0 = data photon source at A  \n 1,2,3 = detectors at B (post\u2010Bell measurement), C (post\u2010Bell measurement), D (output)  \n Ancillary detectors correspond to the other two outputs of each Bell\u2010measurement beam\u2010splitter.\n\nThis design can be extended to N hops simply by adding more Bell\u2010pair sources, more \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to enforce one\u2010way propagation, and extra measurement nodes. The Expert can hand off this abstract target to Pytheus, recover a linear\u2010optics circuit, and write up the first demonstration of a purely chiral, multi\u2010hop entanglement\u2010swapping teleportation network.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The proposal is merely a straightforward N\u2010hop extension of standard entanglement swapping with forbidden backward links (removed_connections); it adds no new measurement tool, channel superposition, or non\u2010trivial causal/coherence effect. To be novel, you must introduce a genuinely new primitive (e.g. coherent superposition of swap orders, programmable non-unitary supermaps, higher-dimensional network metrics) rather than enforcing directionality by graph constraints.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three ways to marry \u201cchiral light\u2013matter interaction\u201d with \u201cquantum photonics\u201d in a Pytheus-compatible quantum network (no state generation):\n    a) A unidirectional N-hop teleportation chain (chiral quantum repeater).\n    b) A chiral ring that cyclically teleports three qubits A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A (a cyclic permutation channel).\n    c) A heralded quantum router (controlled\u2010SWAP) using directional couplers.\n  Step 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n    a) N-hop teleportation is straightforward but adds little beyond directed links.\n    b) The cyclic teleportation ring is a genuine network transformation (a nontrivial permutation supermap) not previously explored, uses only Bell pairs, linear optics, and photon detection, and invokes chirality via removed_connections.\n    c) The quantum router resembles a gate synthesis and drifts toward computing rather than a network\u2010level transformation.\n  Step 3: Choose (b) \u201cChiral cyclic teleportation ring\u201d as the most novel and Pytheus-friendly.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it implements a three-node cyclic permutation channel\u2014A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A\u2014purely by entanglement swapping in a unidirectional (chiral) ring, constituting a non-trivial network supermap rather than mere state generation.\n  Step 5: This is feasible in Pytheus because it only requires abstract Bell\u2010pair sources, single\u2010photon emitters, linear\u2010optical interferometers, number\u2010resolving detectors, and \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to enforce chirality. No cavities, feedback control, or hybrid entanglement are needed.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a proposal for Pytheus to design a \u201cchiral cyclic teleportation ring\u201d across three nodes A, B, C. It realizes the quantum network channel that permutes three unknown qubit inputs (at A, B, C) in a cycle\u2014A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A\u2014using only Bell\u2010pair sources, linear optics, and photon detection:\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to implement the channel  \n  \u2223\u03c8_A\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03d5_B\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03c7_C\u27e9  \u21a6  \u2223\u03c7_D\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03c8_E\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03d5_F\u27e9  \nwhere detectors D, E, F sit at nodes A, B, C respectively, and the mapping is the cyclic permutation (A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A).  \n 1. Place three probabilistic Bell-pair sources on links AB, BC, and CA in a ring.  \n 2. At node B, perform a post-selected Bell measurement between the incoming qubit from A and one photon from the AB pair \u2192 swaps A\u2019s state onto the BC link.  \n 3. At node C, perform a Bell measurement between that swapped photon and one from the BC pair \u2192 swaps A\u2019s state onto the CA link.  \n 4. At node A, perform a Bell measurement between that swapped photon and one from the CA pair \u2192 finalizes C\u2192A teleportation.  \n 5. Simultaneously perform the analogous chain of three measurements starting from B\u2192C\u2192A\u2192B and C\u2192A\u2192B\u2192C\u2014i.e. three interlaced teleportation chains\u2014so that after post-selection each node\u2019s input ends up at the next node clockwise.  \n 6. Enforce chirality (unidirectional coupling) by forbidding any Bell source from connecting \u201cagainst\u201d the ring direction using removed_connections.\n\nVisualization of abstract layout:\n  Sources:  \n    S_AB emits to detectors at A' and B'.  \n    S_BC emits to B\u2033 and C'.  \n    S_CA emits to C\u2033 and A\u2033.  \n  Measurements:  \n    M_B on (A', B'), M_C on (B\u2033, C'), M_A on (C\u2033, A\u2033)  \n  Post-selected detections at A (detector D), B (E), C (F) yield the permuted outputs.\n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{'description': 'Chiral cyclic teleportation ring A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192A',\n 'foldername': 'cyclic_chiral_teleport',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',             # overlap with ideal permutation channel\n 'num_anc': 3,                 # one ancilla detector per Bell measurement\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 20,\n 'target_quantum': [\n   # 6-qubit Choi basis: input(A,B,C)\u2192output(D,E,F)\n   '000000','001100','010001','011101',\n   '100010','101110','110011','111111'\n ],\n 'single_emitters': [],       \n 'amplitudes': [],\n 'tries_per_edge': 5,\n 'removed_connections': [\n   # Forbid any Bell source from connecting opposite ring direction:\n   # no AB\u2192C, no BC\u2192A, no CA\u2192B\n   [0,5],[1,3],[2,4]\n ],\n 'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNode indexing for Pytheus:\n 0,1,2 = outputs of the three Bell sources feeding into the cyclic measurement chain  \n 3,4,5 = final detectors at A (D), B (E), C (F)  \nAncillary detectors are the other ports of each 50:50 beam splitter in each Bell measurement.\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2022 Extend to an N-node chiral cycle by adding more Bell-pair sources and measurements around the ring.  \n  \u2022 Study resource scaling, success probability trade-offs, and robustness against loss.  \n\nThis network\u2010level transformation realizes a nontrivial supermap (the cyclic permutation) purely by linear optics and post-selected entanglement swapping, with chirality enforced via graph constraints."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable Integrated Three-Photon GHZ-Basis Analyzer on Pytheus\n\nAbstract: We implement the target Pytheus-configurable three-photon GHZ-basis analyzer by injecting three unknown photonic qubits and an ancilla Bell pair into a fixed mesh of 50:50 beam splitters augmented with three on-chip electro-optic phase shifters and heralding detectors, thereby unambiguously mapping any incoming triple onto one of the four GHZ basis states. By reprogramming only the EOM voltages\u2014while leaving the linear-optical network unchanged\u2014the same device can project onto the W basis or any rotated three-qubit entangled basis, opening new avenues for adaptive entanglement swapping, secret sharing, and fundamental tests of nonlocality.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement Swapping of 2\u00d72 Toric-Code Logical Qubits via Linear Optics\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate entanglement swapping between two distant logical qubits, each encoded in a minimal 2\u00d72 toric-code patch of four photons at nodes A and D, by performing a post-selected logical Bell measurement on intermediate patches B and C using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, passive linear optics, and ancilla detection. Chiral (unidirectional) coupling is enforced by forbidding any Bell\u2010pair source from connecting \u201cupstream\u201d to \u201cdownstream\u201d backwards (i.e. once a photon leaves A toward B it cannot return), mimicking spin\u2010momentum\u2010locking waveguides in an abstract way. This network can be generalized to N hops, illustrating how chiral couplers reduce resource overhead for long\u2010distance teleportation.\n\nVisualization:\n  - Single\u2010photon source at A emits the data qubit into the network.  \n  - Three Bell\u2010pair sources create pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D (each pair source probabilistic).  \n  - At node B: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the incoming data photon from A and one photon of the AB pair \u2192 swaps entanglement to B\u2013C link.  \n  - For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties.     "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to link \u201cchiral light\u2013matter interaction\u201d and \u201cquantum photonics\u201d in a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum network (no state generation):\n  a) A unidirectional N-hop teleportation chain enforcing chirality by forbidding backward links.\n  b) A cyclic permutation network (A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A) via chiral entanglement swapping around a ring.\n  c) A \u201cquantum switch\u201d supermap: perform two teleportation channels in a superposition of causal orders, controlled by a path\u2010encoded qubit, with chiral one-way couplers.\nStep 2: Evaluate novelty/feasibility:\n  a) Too close to standard N-hop swapping.\n  b) Similar to known cyclic\u2010swap ring.\n  c) The quantum switch is a genuinely new network transformation (indefinite causal order) implementable with linear optics and post\u2010selected Bell measurements; chirality arises by graph constraints (removed_connections).\nStep 3: Choose (c) quantum switch.\nStep 4: Novelty: This implements, for the first time in a purely linear\u2010optical, post\u2010selected experiment, a photonic quantum\u2010switch supermap that applies two teleportation routes (A\u2192B\u2192D, A\u2192C\u2192D) in coherent superposition, controlled by a path qubit. It goes beyond \u201cjust another teleportation chain\u201d by realizing indefinite order.\nStep 5: Feasibility: It only uses abstract Bell\u2010pair sources, single\u2010photon path\u2010encoded control, linear\u2010optical interferometers, number\u2010resolving detectors, and removed_connections to enforce chiral (one\u2010way) links. No cavities, no feedback, no forbidden hybrid entanglement.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a proposal for Pytheus to design a \u201cchiral quantum switch\u201d that coherently superposes two teleportation orders (A\u2192B\u2192D vs. A\u2192C\u2192D), controlled by a path qubit:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to implement the quantum SWITCH supermap which, on input an unknown qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 at A and a control qubit \u22230\u27e9+\u22231\u27e9 (path\u2010encoded), routes the data through two Bell-swap channels in superposition of order:\n  if ctrl=0: teleport A\u2192B then B\u2192D  \n  if ctrl=1: teleport A\u2192C then C\u2192D  \nAfter recombining the paths, the output at D emerges entangled with the control, realizing the coherent superposition of two causal orders. Chirality is enforced by forbidding any Bell source from coupling upstream (removed_connections).\n\nVisualization:\n  1. Control qubit is prepared in superposition of two spatial modes: path0, path1.  \n  2. Data qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 enters both paths.  \n  3. On path0: Bell-pair sources on links AB and BD; post-selected Bell measurement at B, then at D.  \n     On path1: Bell-pair sources on AC and CD; Bell measurement at C, then at D.  \n  4. The two paths are recombined on a beam splitter to erase \u201cwhich-order\u201d information.  \n  5. D\u2019s detector outputs the teleported qubit; the control path interferometer yields the superposition of orders.\n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{'description': 'Chiral quantum switch (indefinite teleportation order)',\n 'foldername': 'chiral_quantum_switch',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 50,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',               # overlap with ideal SWITCH Choi process\n 'num_anc': 4,                    # two ancillas per Bell measurement\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 30,\n 'target_quantum': [               # nonzero basis of the SWITCH Choi state (control+input+output)\n   '000000','001001','010010','011011',\n   '100100','101101','110110','111111'\n ],\n 'single_emitters': [0],           # node 0 = data source\n 'amplitudes': [],\n 'tries_per_edge': 5,\n 'removed_connections': [\n   # forbid any Bell source from sending photons backward or cross-coupling:\n   [0,4],[1,5],[2,3]\n ],\n 'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNode indexing for Pytheus:\n 0 = data photon source (A)  \n 1 = control path beam splitter (ancilla modes)  \n 2,3 = detectors for first Bell measurement (on B or C depending on path)  \n 4 = detectors for second Bell measurement (at D)  \n 5 = final recombined detector (output)  \n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Extend to multi-order supermaps by adding more Bell-pair stages and path modes.  \n \u2022 Study success\u2010probability scaling, coherence visibility, and robustness to loss.\n\nThis design tasks Pytheus with generating the linear-optical circuit that realizes the photonic quantum switch\u2014an operationally indefinite causal order channel\u2014using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, passive optics, and post-selected photon detection, with chirality enforced via graph constraints."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable Integrated Three-Photon GHZ-Basis Analyzer on Pytheus\n\nAbstract: We implement the target Pytheus-configurable three-photon GHZ-basis analyzer by injecting three unknown photonic qubits and an ancilla Bell pair into a fixed mesh of 50:50 beam splitters augmented with three on-chip electro-optic phase shifters and heralding detectors, thereby unambiguously mapping any incoming triple onto one of the four GHZ basis states. By reprogramming only the EOM voltages\u2014while leaving the linear-optical network unchanged\u2014the same device can project onto the W basis or any rotated three-qubit entangled basis, opening new avenues for adaptive entanglement swapping, secret sharing, and fundamental tests of nonlocality.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement Swapping of 2\u00d72 Toric-Code Logical Qubits via Linear Optics\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate entanglement swapping between two distant logical qubits, each encoded in a minimal 2\u00d72 toric-code patch of four photons at nodes A and D, by performing a post-selected logical Bell measurement on intermediate patches B and C using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, passive linear optics, and ancilla detection. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Dissipative Cyclic Entanglement Shifter for Photonic Bell Pairs\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a static, single-step dissipative network primitive that cyclically reconfigures three pre-existing photonic Bell pairs (modes AB, CD, EF) into the target six-photon cyclic permutation subspace, yielding new entangled pairs AD, CF, and EB via a two-ancilla-photon heralding event. By mixing only the \u201cmiddle\u201d modes with two ancilla photons through beam splitters and phase shifters\u2014and detecting exactly one photon on each ancilla detector\u2014this passive linear-optical protocol achieves the desired entanglement shift without active feedback or cavities and plugs directly into the Pytheus toolkit.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). By mixing modes A\u2082 and B\u2081 with ancilla photons in an optimized interferometer and employing photon-number-resolving detection, the scheme heralds successful swapping and compression of multi-level entanglement into a qubit link between the Kerr and transmon nodes without feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Hybrid-Dimensional Qubit\u2013Qutrit Entanglement Swapping via a Full 2\u00d73 Bell Measurement\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate in PyTheus a probabilistic protocol that entangles a Rydberg-encoded qubit (mode 0) with a condensate-encoded qutrit (mode 3) by performing a full 2\u00d73 Bell measurement on a shared qubit\u2013qutrit mediator (modes 1&2).  Conditioned on one of the six generalized Bell outcomes, this linear-optics and number-resolving detection scheme heralds the target qubit\u2013qutrit Bell state \u201600\u27e9+ei\u03c6\u201612\u27e9/\u221a2 across the two distinct Hilbert spaces without feedback, hyper-entanglement, or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nSymmetry-Protected Bound-State Router for Heralded Bell-State Generation in a Three-Node Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe employ a C\u2083-symmetric tritter to engineer a symmetry-protected bound state in the continuum (BIC) that traps an intermediate photon until a three\u2010fold no-click heralding event triggers entanglement swapping between remote nodes. Chiral (unidirectional) coupling is enforced by forbidding any Bell\u2010pair source from connecting \u201cupstream\u201d to \u201cdownstream\u201d backwards (i.e. once a photon leaves A toward B it cannot return), mimicking spin\u2010momentum\u2010locking waveguides in an abstract way. This network can be generalized to N hops, illustrating how chiral couplers reduce resource overhead for long\u2010distance teleportation.\n\nVisualization:\n  - Single\u2010photon source at A emits the data qubit into the network.  \n  - For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to link \u201cchiral light\u2013matter interaction\u201d and \u201cquantum photonics\u201d in a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum network (no state generation):\n  a) A unidirectional N-hop teleportation chain enforcing chirality by forbidding backward links.\n  b) A cyclic permutation network (A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A) via chiral entanglement swapping around a ring.\n  c) A \u201cquantum switch\u201d supermap: perform two teleportation channels in a superposition of causal orders, controlled by a path\u2010encoded qubit, with chiral one-way couplers.\nStep 2: Evaluate novelty/feasibility:\n  a) Too close to standard N-hop swapping.\n  b) Similar to known cyclic\u2010swap ring.\n  c) The quantum switch is a genuinely new network transformation (indefinite causal order) implementable with linear optics and post\u2010selected Bell measurements; chirality arises by graph constraints (removed_connections).\nStep 3: Choose (c) quantum switch.\nStep 4: Novelty: This implements, for the first time in a purely linear\u2010optical, post\u2010selected experiment, a photonic quantum\u2010switch supermap that applies two teleportation routes (A\u2192B\u2192D, A\u2192C\u2192D) in coherent superposition, controlled by a path qubit. It goes beyond \u201cjust another teleportation chain\u201d by realizing indefinite order.\nStep 5: Feasibility: It only uses abstract Bell\u2010pair sources, single\u2010photon path\u2010encoded control, linear\u2010optical interferometers, number\u2010resolving detectors, and removed_connections to enforce chiral (one\u2010way) links. No cavities, no feedback, no forbidden hybrid entanglement.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a proposal for Pytheus to design a \u201cchiral quantum switch\u201d that coherently superposes two teleportation orders (A\u2192B\u2192D vs. A\u2192C\u2192D), controlled by a path qubit:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to implement the quantum SWITCH supermap which, on input an unknown qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 at A and a control qubit \u22230\u27e9+\u22231\u27e9 (path\u2010encoded), routes the data through two Bell-swap channels in superposition of order:\n  if ctrl=0: teleport A\u2192B then B\u2192D  \n  if ctrl=1: teleport A\u2192C then C\u2192D  \nAfter recombining the paths, the output at D emerges entangled with the control, realizing the coherent superposition of two causal orders. Chirality is enforced by forbidding any Bell source from coupling upstream (removed_connections).\n\nVisualization:\n  1. Control qubit is prepared in superposition of two spatial modes: path0, path1.  \n  2. Data qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 enters both paths.  \n  3. On path0: Bell-pair sources on links AB and BD; post-selected Bell measurement at B, then at D.  \n     On path1: Bell-pair sources on AC and CD; Bell measurement at C, then at D.  \n  4. The two paths are recombined on a beam splitter to erase \u201cwhich-order\u201d information.  \n  5. D\u2019s detector outputs the teleported qubit; the control path interferometer yields the superposition of orders.\n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{'description': 'Chiral quantum switch (indefinite teleportation order)',\n 'foldername': 'chiral_quantum_switch',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 50,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',               # overlap with ideal SWITCH Choi process\n 'num_anc': 4,                    # two ancillas per Bell measurement\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 30,\n 'target_quantum': [               # forbid any Bell source from sending photons backward or cross-coupling:\n   [0,4],[1,5],[2,3]\n ],\n 'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNode indexing for Pytheus:\n 0 = data photon source (A)  \n 1 = control path beam splitter (ancilla modes)  \n 2,3 = detectors for first Bell measurement (on B or C depending on path)  \n 4 = detectors for second Bell measurement (at D)  \n 5 = final recombined detector (output)  \n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Extend to multi-order supermaps by adding more Bell-pair stages and path modes.  \n \u2022 Study success\u2010probability scaling, coherence visibility, and robustness to loss.\n\nThis design tasks Pytheus with generating the linear-optical circuit that realizes the photonic quantum switch\u2014an operationally indefinite causal order channel\u2014using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, passive optics, and post-selected photon detection, with chirality enforced via graph constraints.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This idea replicates the indefinite\u2010order entanglement\u2010swapping (quantum SWITCH) already present in the suggestion \u201cImplementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders.\u201d To be novel, you need a genuinely new measurement supermap or network effect rather than restating the same causal\u2010order superposition with removed_connections constraints.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!!     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to combine \u201cchiral light\u2013matter interaction\u201d and \u201cquantum photonics\u201d into a network (no pure state generation):\n    a) A unidirectional N\u2010hop teleportation chain (chiral quantum repeater).\n    b) A cyclic chiral entanglement\u2010swapping ring (permutation supermap).\n    c) A superposition of two chiral teleportation routes (network\u2010path superposition).\n  Step 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n    a) Too close to standard chaining.\n    b) Similar to known cyclic swap.\n    c) Superposing two distinct, chiral entanglement\u2010swapping networks in one interferometer is a new type of network transformation\u2014\u201cquantum superposition of network topologies.\u201d\n    All rely only on Bell\u2010pair sources, single\u2010photon sources, linear optics, detectors, and removed_connections to enforce chirality\u2014Pytheus\u2010compatible.\n  Step 3: Pick (c).\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it realizes the coherent superposition of two different teleportation networks (A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D vs. A\u2192C\u2192B\u2192D), exploring interference between distinct quantum\u2010network topologies.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus: just abstract sources, beamsplitters, detectors, and removed_connections to block backward or cross\u2010arm couplings; no cavities, no feedback, no hybrid entanglement; perfectly fits Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a proposal for Pytheus to design a \u201cchiral network\u2010path superposition\u201d experiment. It teleports an unknown qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 from node A to node D via two distinct chiral entanglement\u2010swapping routes\u2014A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D and A\u2192C\u2192B\u2192D\u2014coherently superposed by an initial and final beam splitter.\n\nExplanation:\n1. A single\u2010photon source at A emits the data qubit and feeds it into a 50:50 beam splitter \u2192 two spatial arms (paths 0 and 1).  \n2. Path 0 implements entanglement swapping along the chiral chain A\u2192B (Bell pair on AB) then B\u2192C (Bell pair on BC).  \n   Path 1 implements entanglement swapping along A\u2192C (Bell pair on AC) then C\u2192B (Bell pair on CB).  \n3. After the two swap stages in each arm, the two resulting photons recombine on a second 50:50 beam splitter.  \n4. Post\u2010selecting on successful detections at B and C in each arm and the final detector at D yields a teleportation channel A\u2192D.  \n5. Because the data qubit traveled through both network topologies in superposition, the output exhibits interference fringes as a function of relative phase\u2014demonstrating \u201csuperposed network topologies\u201d in a chiral photonic setting.\n\nVisualization of logical layout (top view):\n  [A data source]  \n       \u2502  \n      BS_in  \n     \u2571    \u2572  \n  arm0    arm1  \n   \u2502       \u2502  \n  Swap0_1  Swap1_1   \u2190 Bell meas. stage 1 on AB\u2013BC vs. AC\u2013CB  \n   \u2502       \u2502  \n  Swap0_2  Swap1_2   \u2190 Bell meas. stage 2  \n     \u2572    \u2571  \n      BS_out  \n       \u2502  \n      [D detector]\n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{\n  'description': 'Superposition of two chiral teleportation routes A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D vs. A\u2192C\u2192B\u2192D',\n  'foldername': 'chiral_route_superposition',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'ftol': 1e-6,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',            # overlap with ideal identity channel A\u2192D\n  'num_anc': 4,                 # two ancilla detections per swap stage\n  'num_pre': 1,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'imaginary': False,\n  'safe_hist': True,\n  'samples': 20,\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],# identity (teleportation) channel\u2019s Choi basis\n  'single_emitters': [0],       # node 0 = data source at A\n  'amplitudes': [],\n  'tries_per_edge': 5,\n  'removed_connections': [\n    # enforce chiral, arm\u2010separated links and forbid backward/cross couplings\n    [0,4], [0,5],  # data source (0) cannot feed wrong Bell\u2010meas. ports\n    [1,6], [1,7]   # Bell\u2010pair source on AB/BC cannot feed AC/CB ports\n  ],\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNode indexing guide (to be adapted by the Expert):\n 0 = data\u2010photon emitter (A)  \n 1\u20134 = four Bell\u2010pair sources:  \n     S_AB (emits to 2,3), S_BC (3,4) in arm 0;  \n     S_AC (emits to 5,6), S_CB (6,7) in arm 1.  \n 8 = BS_in second output (ancilla detector), 9 = BS_out recombined path \u2192 D.  \n Ancilla detectors are the unused ports of each 50:50 beamsplitter in both BS_in and BS_out, and the two unused ports at B and C measurements.\n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Add more arms (network topologies) to superpose arbitrarily many entanglement\u2010swapping graphs.  \n \u2022 Study interference between different network architectures, resource costs, phase sensitivity.  \n\nThis setup realizes the first demonstration of a superposition of chiral quantum\u2010network topologies, merging chiral light\u2013matter constraints (enforced via graph \u201cremoved_connections\u201d) with quantum\u2010photonic entanglement\u2010swapping in one coherent experiment."
