In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. Chiral (unidirectional) coupling is enforced by forbidding any Bell\u2010pair source from connecting \u201cupstream\u201d to \u201cdownstream\u201d backwards (i.e. once a photon leaves A toward B it cannot return), mimicking spin\u2010momentum\u2010locking waveguides in an abstract way. This network can be generalized to N hops, illustrating how chiral couplers reduce resource overhead for long\u2010distance teleportation.\n\nVisualization:\n  - Single\u2010photon source at A emits the data qubit into the network.  \n  - Three Bell\u2010pair sources create pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D (each pair source probabilistic).  \n  - At node B: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the incoming data photon from A and one photon of the AB pair \u2192 swaps entanglement to B\u2013C link.  \n  - At node C: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the swapped photon from B\u2013C and one photon of the C\u2013D pair \u2192 final entanglement between A data and D.  \n  - After post\u2010selection, the output qubit emerges at D with the state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9, completing a two\u2010dimensional teleportation channel \u22230\u27e9\u2192\u22230\u27e9, \u22231\u27e9\u2192\u22231\u27e9.\n  - It realizes the quantum network channel that permutes three unknown qubit inputs (at A, B, C) in a cycle\u2014A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A\u2014using only Bell\u2010pair sources, linear optics, and photon detection:\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to implement the channel  \n  \u2223\u03c8_A\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03d5_B\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03c7_C\u27e9  \u21a6  \u2223\u03c7_D\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03c8_E\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03d5_F\u27e9  \nwhere detectors D, E, F sit at nodes A, B, C respectively, and the mapping is the cyclic permutation (A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A).  \n 1. Place three probabilistic Bell-pair sources on links AB, BC, and CA in a ring.  \n 2. At node B, perform a post-selected Bell measurement between the incoming qubit from A and one photon from the AB pair \u2192 swaps A\u2019s state onto the BC link.  \n 3. At node C, perform a Bell measurement between that swapped photon and one from the BC pair \u2192 swaps A\u2019s state onto the CA link.  \n 4. At node A, perform a Bell measurement between that swapped photon and one from the CA pair \u2192 finalizes C\u2192A teleportation.  \n 5. Simultaneously perform the analogous chain of three measurements starting from B\u2192C\u2192A\u2192B and C\u2192A\u2192B\u2192C\u2014i.e. three interlaced teleportation chains\u2014so that after post-selection each node\u2019s input ends up at the next node clockwise.  \n 6. Enforce chirality (unidirectional coupling) by forbidding any Bell source from connecting \u201cagainst\u201d the ring direction using removed_connections.\n\nVisualization of abstract layout:\n  Sources:  \n    S_AB emits to detectors at A' and B'.  \n    S_BC emits to B\u2033 and C'.  \n    S_CA emits to C\u2033 and A\u2033.  \n  Measurements:  \n    M_B on (A', B'), M_C on (B\u2033, C'), M_A on (C\u2033, A\u2033)  \n  Post-selected detections at A (detector D), B (E), C (F) yield the permuted outputs.\n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{'description': 'Chiral cyclic teleportation ring A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192A',\n 'foldername': 'cyclic_chiral_teleport',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',             # overlap with ideal permutation channel\n 'num_anc': 3,                 # one ancilla detector per Bell measurement\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 20,\n 'target_quantum': [\n   # LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm 3 Pytheus-compatible ways to marry \u201cchiral light\u2013matter interaction\u201d and \u201cquantum photonics\u201d in a non-state-generation quantum-network:\n  a) A fully chiral N-hop teleportation chain (repeater) with forbidden backward links.\n  b) A chiral cyclic entanglement-swap ring (permutation channel) around three or more nodes.\n  c) A chiral entanglement-purification plus swapping primitive at a central node\u2014i.e. two imperfect Bell pairs (A\u2013B and B\u2013C) are purified and simultaneously swapped into a single high-fidelity A\u2013C pair via a post-selected CNOT at B, with one-way (chiral) couplings.\nStep 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n  a) Too trivial an extension of standard repeater chains.\n  b) Already covered by cyclic\u2010swap proposals.\n  c) Purification+swapping in one go is a genuinely new network transform for Pytheus: it goes beyond plain entanglement swapping or purification alone, and no Pytheus example covers a joint Bell-pair purification/swap in a chiral setting.\nStep 3: Select (c).\nStep 4: Novelty: This setup implements for the first time in a passive, post-selected linear-optics network a combined entanglement-distillation and entanglement-swapping operation (\u201cpurify-swap\u201d) at a chiral node. It\u2019s a new CPTP map: two noisy Bell channels \u2192 one purified, long-range Bell channel.\nStep 5: Feasibility: Pytheus can build the needed post-selected CNOT from Bell-pair sources, beam splitters, and number-resolving detectors. \u201cremoved_connections\u201d encodes the unidirectional (chiral) edges (A\u2192B and B\u2192C only). No cavities, no feedback, no hybrid entanglement\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s scope.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a target for Pytheus: a \u201cchiral entanglement purification\u2009+\u2009swapping\u201d primitive.  Two noisy Bell-pair sources create entangled photon pairs on links A\u2013B and B\u2013C.  At node B these two halves undergo a post-selected, linear-optic CNOT gate, and the target qubit is measured in the Z basis.  Conditioned on the \u201c0\u201d outcome at B, the remaining photons at A and C emerge in a higher-fidelity Bell state.  All couplings are chiral (one-way): photons only flow A\u2192B and B\u2192C (no back-routing), enforced by removed_connections.\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources:\n    S_AB emits to modes A (0) and B_ctrl (1)\n    S_BC emits to modes B_tgt (2) and C (3)\n  Node B:\n    Perform post-selected CNOT(control=mode 1, target=mode 2)\n    Measure mode 2 in the {0,1} basis; herald on outcome \u201c0\u201d\n  Output:\n    Modes 0 (A) and 3 (C) carry a purified Bell pair \u222300>+\u222311> (unnormalized)\n\nPytheus configuration template:\n{'description': 'Chiral entanglement purification + swapping A\u2013B\u2013C \u2192 purified A\u2013C',\n 'foldername': 'chiral_purify_swap',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n 'edges_tried': 30,\n 'ftol': 1e-06,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',               # maximize overlap with ideal A\u2013C Bell\n 'num_anc': 1,                    # heralding detector for the CNOT target\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 20,\n 'target_quantum': ['00','11'],  # ideal Bell state on modes [0,3]\n 'single_emitters': [],          \n 'amplitudes': [],\n 'tries_per_edge': 5,\n 'removed_connections': [\n   [0,3],  # forbid the A\u2013B source from sending to C\n   [2,0]   # forbid the B\u2013C source from sending to A\n ],\n 'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNode indexing:\n 0 = detector at A  \n 1 = control port of post-selected CNOT at B  \n 2 = target port of post-selected CNOT at B (measured for herald)  \n 3 = detector at C  \n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Cascade multiple purification\u2009+\u2009swap stages for multi-segment chiral repeaters.  \n \u2022 Replace the single CNOT with higher-dimensional purification circuits.  \n \u2022 Compare performance under varying loss and noise.\n\nThis target asks Pytheus to find the optimal linear-optical circuit implementing a heralded CNOT and measurement for entanglement purification and swapping in one step, under strictly chiral (one-way) connectivity, realizing a new quantum-network CPTP map.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The protocol duplicates existing static LOQC purification\u2009+\u2009swap schemes with only a graph constraint change.     "output": "Here is a proposal for Pytheus to design a \u201cchiral (2,3)-threshold quantum secret-sharing\u201d network.  This realizes the CPTP map that takes an unknown qubit at A and distributes three \u201cshares\u201d at B, C, D such that any two can later reconstruct the input.  All photon\u2013emitter couplings are one-way (chiral), enforced by removed_connections.  Only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, linear optics and post-selected photon detection are used\u2014no cavities, feedback or hybrid entanglement.\n\nExplanation:\n 1. Bell-pair sources:\n    \u2022 S\u2081 on links A\u2013B  \n    \u2022 S\u2082 on B\u2013C  \n    \u2022 S\u2083 on B\u2013D  \n 2. At node B: fuse the two pairs S\u2082, S\u2083 into a three-party GHZ resource shared among B, C, D via a post-selected linear-optical fusion (beam splitters + two ancilla detectors \u2192 herald successful GHZ).  \n 3. At node A: perform a post-selected Bell measurement between the input qubit (emitter at A) and the B-leg of the GHZ resource (from S\u2081), heralding \u201cno-correction\u201d outcome.  \n 4. Upon success, the remaining photons at B, C, D carry the three secret shares (they form a GHZ-type encoding of the original qubit).  Any two of these parties can later apply a Bell-swap to reconstruct the input.  \n 5. Chirality is enforced by forbidding backward or cross couplings:\n       removed_connections blocks any source (S\u2082,S\u2083) from sending to A, and S\u2081 from sending to C or D.\n\nVisualization (abstract):\n   S\u2081 emits to  A_meas_port  \u2500\u2500\u252c\u2500\u2500 Bell-meas @ A \u2500\u2500\u25b6  herald out  \n                             \u2502  \n   S\u2082 emits to  B_fuse_port1 \u2500\u253c\u2500\u2500 Fusion @ B \u2500\u25b6 C_share  \n                             \u2502                \u2510       D_share  \n   S\u2083 emits to  B_fuse_port2 \u2500\u2534  \n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{\n  'description':      'Chiral (2,3)-threshold quantum secret sharing A\u2192{B,C,D}',\n  'foldername':       'chiral_secret_sharing',\n  'bulk_thr':         0.01,\n  'edges_tried':      30,\n  'ftol':             1e-6,\n  'loss_func':        'cr',             # maximize overlap with ideal secret-sharing Choi\n  'num_anc':          2,                # two ancilla detectors at B for GHZ fusion\n  'num_pre':          1,\n  'optimizer':        'L-BFGS-B',\n  'imaginary':        False,\n  'safe_hist':        True,\n  'samples':          20,\n  'target_quantum':   ['0000','1111'],  # Choi\u2010vector of |0,000>+|1,111> on (in;B,C,D)\n  'single_emitters':  [0],              # node 0 = input qubit at A\n  'amplitudes':       [],\n  'tries_per_edge':   5,\n  'removed_connections': [\n    [2,0],  # forbid S\u2082 (node 2) \u2192 A\n    [3,0],  # forbid S\u2083 (node 3) \u2192 A\n    [1,4],[1,5]  # forbid S\u2081 (node 1) \u2192 C (4) or D (5)\n  ],\n  'number_resolving':  True\n}\n\nNode indexing guide (to be finalized by Expert):\n 0 = input qubit emitter at A  \n 1 = Bell source S\u2081 outputs to A_meas_port & B_meas_port  \n 2 = Bell source S\u2082 outputs to B_fuse_port1 & C (share)  \n 3 = Bell source S\u2083 outputs to B_fuse_port2 & D (share)  \n 4,5 = final share detectors at C, D  \n Ancilla detectors are the unused ports at the two beam splitters in the GHZ fusion circuit at B and at the Bell measurement at A.\n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Cascade multiple (A\u2013B\u2013C) purification+fusion stages for longer one-way repeater chains.  \n \u2022 Extend to 2\u2192N threshold schemes by adding more Bell pairs and larger fusion measurements.  \n \u2022 Study success probability, share-reconstruction fidelity, and robustness against loss under chiral constraints.\n\nThis network-level transformation is neither plain state generation nor gate synthesis but the first passive, post-selected photonic implementation of a directional (chiral) quantum secret-sharing channel. It combines chiral light\u2013matter constraints (via removed_connections) with entanglement swapping and GHZ fusion entirely in the Pytheus framework."

Chiral (unidirectional) coupling is enforced by forbidding any Bell\u2010pair source from connecting \u201cupstream\u201d to \u201cdownstream\u201d backwards (i.e. once a photon leaves A toward B it cannot return), mimicking spin\u2010momentum\u2010locking waveguides in an abstract way. It realizes the quantum network channel that permutes three unknown qubit inputs (at A, B, C) in a cycle\u2014A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A\u2014using only Bell\u2010pair sources, linear optics, and photon detection:\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to implement the channel  \n  \u2223\u03c8_A\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03d5_B\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03c7_C\u27e9  \u21a6  \u2223\u03c7_D\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03c8_E\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03d5_F\u27e9  \nwhere detectors D, E, F sit at nodes A, B, C respectively, and the mapping is the cyclic permutation (A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A).  \n 1. Place three probabilistic Bell-pair sources on links AB, BC, and CA in a ring.  \n 2. At node B, perform a post-selected Bell measurement between the incoming qubit from A and one photon from the AB pair \u2192 swaps A\u2019s state onto the BC link.  \n 3. At node C, perform a Bell measurement between that swapped photon and one from the BC pair \u2192 swaps A\u2019s state onto the CA link.  \n 4. At node A, perform a Bell measurement between that swapped photon and one from the CA pair \u2192 finalizes C\u2192A teleportation.  \n 5. Simultaneously perform the analogous chain of three measurements starting from B\u2192C\u2192A\u2192B and C\u2192A\u2192B\u2192C\u2014i.e. three interlaced teleportation chains\u2014so that after post-selection each node\u2019s input ends up at the next node clockwise.  \n 6. Chirality is enforced by forbidding any Bell source from coupling upstream (removed_connections).\n\nVisualization:\n  1. It teleports an unknown qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 from node A to node D via two distinct chiral entanglement\u2010swapping routes\u2014A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D and A\u2192C\u2192B\u2192D\u2014coherently superposed by an initial and final beam splitter.\n\nExplanation:\n1. A single\u2010photon source at A emits the data qubit and feeds it into a 50:50 beam splitter \u2192 two spatial arms (paths 0 and 1).  \n2. Path 0 implements entanglement swapping along the chiral chain A\u2192B (Bell pair on AB) then B\u2192C (Bell pair on BC).  \n   Path 1 implements entanglement swapping along A\u2192C (Bell pair on AC) then C\u2192B (Bell pair on CB).  \n3. After the two swap stages in each arm, the two resulting photons recombine on a second 50:50 beam splitter.  \n4. Post\u2010selecting on successful detections at B and C in each arm and the final detector at D yields a teleportation channel A\u2192D.  \n5. Because the data qubit traveled through both network topologies in superposition, the output exhibits interference fringes as a function of relative phase\u2014demonstrating \u201csuperposed network topologies\u201d in a chiral photonic setting.\n\nVisualization of logical layout (top view):\n  [A data source]  \n       \u2502  \n      BS_in  \n     \u2571    \u2572  \n  arm0    arm1  \n   \u2502       \u2502  \n  Swap0_1  Swap1_1   \u2190 Bell meas. stage 1 on AB\u2013BC vs. AC\u2013CB  \n   \u2502       \u2502  \n  Swap0_2  Swap1_2   \u2190 Bell meas. stage 2  \n     \u2572    \u2571  \n      BS_out  \n       \u2502  \n      [D detector]\n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{\n  'description': 'Superposition of two chiral teleportation routes A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D vs. A\u2192C\u2192B\u2192D',\n  'foldername': 'chiral_route_superposition',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'ftol': 1e-6,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',            # overlap with ideal identity channel A\u2192D\n  'num_anc': 4,                 # two ancilla detections per swap stage\n  'num_pre': 1,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'imaginary': False,\n  'safe_hist': True,\n  'samples': 20,\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],# identity (teleportation) channel\u2019s Choi basis\n  'single_emitters': [0],       # node 0 = data source at A\n  'amplitudes': [],\n  'tries_per_edge': 5,\n  'removed_connections': [\n    # enforce chiral, arm\u2010separated links and forbid backward/cross couplings\n    [0,4], [0,5],  # data source (0) cannot feed wrong Bell\u2010meas. ports\n    [1,6], [1,7]   # Bell\u2010pair source on AB/BC cannot feed AC/CB ports\n  ],\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNode indexing guide (to be adapted by the Expert):\n 0 = data\u2010photon emitter (A)  \n 1\u20134 = four Bell\u2010pair sources:  \n     S_AB (emits to 2,3), S_BC (3,4) in arm 0;  \n     S_AC (emits to 5,6), S_CB (6,7) in arm 1.  \n 8 = BS_in second output (ancilla detector), 9 = BS_out recombined path \u2192 D.  \n Ancilla detectors are the unused ports of each 50:50 beamsplitter in both BS_in and BS_out, and the two unused ports at B and C measurements.\n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Add more arms (network topologies) to superpose arbitrarily many entanglement\u2010swapping graphs.  \n \u2022 Study interference between different network architectures, resource costs, phase sensitivity.  \n\nThis setup realizes the first demonstration of a superposition of chiral quantum\u2010network topologies, merging chiral light\u2013matter constraints (enforced via graph \u201cremoved_connections\u201d) with quantum\u2010photonic entanglement\u2010swapping in one coherent experiment.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme duplicates existing indefinite-order or superposed-path teleportation primitives\u2014no new supermap or higher-dimensional network metric is introduced.     "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable Integrated Three-Photon GHZ-Basis Analyzer on Pytheus\n\nAbstract: We implement the target Pytheus-configurable three-photon GHZ-basis analyzer by injecting three unknown photonic qubits and an ancilla Bell pair into a fixed mesh of 50:50 beam splitters augmented with three on-chip electro-optic phase shifters and heralding detectors, thereby unambiguously mapping any incoming triple onto one of the four GHZ basis states. By reprogramming only the EOM voltages\u2014while leaving the linear-optical network unchanged\u2014the same device can project onto the W basis or any rotated three-qubit entangled basis, opening new avenues for adaptive entanglement swapping, secret sharing, and fundamental tests of nonlocality.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement Swapping of 2\u00d72 Toric-Code Logical Qubits via Linear Optics\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate entanglement swapping between two distant logical qubits, each encoded in a minimal 2\u00d72 toric-code patch of four photons at nodes A and D, by performing a post-selected logical Bell measurement on intermediate patches B and C using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, passive linear optics, and ancilla detection. The successful eight-fold coincidence projects detectors 0\u20133 and 12\u201315 onto the unnormalized target quantum state  \n[\"00000000\", \"00001111\", \"11110000\", \"11111111\", \"00110011\", \"00111100\", \"11000011\", \"11001100\"],  \nheralding a fault-tolerant logical Bell pair between A and D without any feed-forward correction.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a proposal for Pytheus to design a \u201cchiral, multi\u2010hop teleportation chain\u201d that implements directional entanglement swapping (i.e. a chiral quantum repeater) between four nodes A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to teleport an unknown qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 from node A to node D by performing sequential entanglement\u2010swapping steps at intermediate nodes B and C, using only probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, single\u2010photon sources, linear optics, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. Chiral (unidirectional) coupling is enforced by forbidding any Bell\u2010pair source from connecting \u201cupstream\u201d to \u201cdownstream\u201d backwards (i.e. once a photon leaves A toward B it cannot return), mimicking spin\u2010momentum\u2010locking waveguides in an abstract way. This network can be generalized to N hops, illustrating how chiral couplers reduce resource overhead for long\u2010distance teleportation.\n\nVisualization:\n  - Single\u2010photon source at A emits the data qubit into the network.  \n  - Three Bell\u2010pair sources create pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D (each pair source probabilistic).  \n  - At node B: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the incoming data photon from A and one photon of the AB pair \u2192 swaps entanglement to B\u2013C link.  \n  - At node C: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the swapped photon from B\u2013C and one photon of the C\u2013D pair \u2192 final entanglement between A data and D.  \n  - After post\u2010selection, the output qubit emerges at D with the state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9, completing a two\u2010dimensional teleportation channel \u22230\u27e9\u2192\u22230\u27e9, \u22231\u27e9\u2192\u22231\u27e9.\n  - No direct source\u2010detector connections backward along the chain, enforced by removed_connections to encode chirality.\n\nConfig Template for Pytheus:\n{'description': 'Chiral 3\u2010hop teleportation chain A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D',\n 'foldername': 'chiral_3hop_teleport',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,    # loosened threshold for post\u2010selection\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',   # count\u2010rate overlap with ideal teleportation channel\n 'num_anc': 4,        # ancilla detectors for two Bell measurements (2 each)\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 20,\n 'target_quantum': ['00','11'],  # ideal identity channel on logical qubit A\u2192D\n 'single_emitters': [0],         # node 0 = A data photon\n 'amplitudes': [],\n 'tries_per_edge': 5,\n 'removed_connections': [\n     # forbid direct A\u2192C, A\u2192D, B\u2192D sources\n     [0,2],[0,3],[1,3]\n ],\n 'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNodes indexing:\n 0 = data photon source at A  \n 1,2,3 = detectors at B (post\u2010Bell measurement), C (post\u2010Bell measurement), D (output)  \n Ancillary detectors correspond to the other two outputs of each Bell\u2010measurement beam\u2010splitter.\n\nThis design can be extended to N hops simply by adding more Bell\u2010pair sources, more \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to enforce one\u2010way propagation, and extra measurement nodes. The Expert can hand off this abstract target to Pytheus, recover a linear\u2010optics circuit, and write up the first demonstration of a purely chiral, multi\u2010hop entanglement\u2010swapping teleportation network.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This \u201cchiral multi\u2010hop teleportation chain\u201d is just the textbook sequential entanglement\u2010swapping repeater extended with a removed_connections trick to enforce one\u2010way links. It offers no new Bell\u2010measurement primitive or exotic causality superposition beyond standard multi\u2010link swapping (see, e.g., basic two\u2010link entanglement swapping, temporal\u2010mode multiplexing, flux\u2010controlled chiral teleportation routing). It therefore lacks the novelty threshold for a PRL\u2010worthy target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The proposal is merely a straightforward N\u2010hop extension of standard entanglement swapping with forbidden backward links (removed_connections); it adds no new measurement tool, channel superposition, or non\u2010trivial causal/coherence effect. To be novel, you must introduce a genuinely new primitive (e.g. coherent superposition of swap orders, programmable non-unitary supermaps, higher-dimensional network metrics) rather than enforcing directionality by graph constraints.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a proposal for Pytheus to design a \u201cchiral cyclic teleportation ring\u201d across three nodes A, B, C. It realizes the quantum network channel that permutes three unknown qubit inputs (at A, B, C) in a cycle\u2014A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A\u2014using only Bell\u2010pair sources, linear optics, and photon detection:\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to implement the channel  \n  \u2223\u03c8_A\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03d5_B\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03c7_C\u27e9  \u21a6  \u2223\u03c7_D\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03c8_E\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03d5_F\u27e9  \nwhere detectors D, E, F sit at nodes A, B, C respectively, and the mapping is the cyclic permutation (A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A).  \n 1. Place three probabilistic Bell-pair sources on links AB, BC, and CA in a ring.  \n 2. At node B, perform a post-selected Bell measurement between the incoming qubit from A and one photon from the AB pair \u2192 swaps A\u2019s state onto the BC link.  \n 3. At node C, perform a Bell measurement between that swapped photon and one from the BC pair \u2192 swaps A\u2019s state onto the CA link.  \n 4. At node A, perform a Bell measurement between that swapped photon and one from the CA pair \u2192 finalizes C\u2192A teleportation.  \n 5. Simultaneously perform the analogous chain of three measurements starting from B\u2192C\u2192A\u2192B and C\u2192A\u2192B\u2192C\u2014i.e. three interlaced teleportation chains\u2014so that after post-selection each node\u2019s input ends up at the next node clockwise.  \n 6. Enforce chirality (unidirectional coupling) by forbidding any Bell source from connecting \u201cagainst\u201d the ring direction using removed_connections.\n\nVisualization of abstract layout:\n  Sources:  \n    S_AB emits to detectors at A' and B'.  \n    S_BC emits to B\u2033 and C'.  \n    S_CA emits to C\u2033 and A\u2033.  \n  Measurements:  \n    M_B on (A', B'), M_C on (B\u2033, C'), M_A on (C\u2033, A\u2033)  \n  Post-selected detections at A (detector D), B (E), C (F) yield the permuted outputs.\n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{'description': 'Chiral cyclic teleportation ring A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192A',\n 'foldername': 'cyclic_chiral_teleport',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',             # overlap with ideal permutation channel\n 'num_anc': 3,                 # one ancilla detector per Bell measurement\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 20,\n 'target_quantum': [\n   # {
    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. Chiral (unidirectional) coupling is enforced by forbidding any Bell\u2010pair source from connecting \u201cupstream\u201d to \u201cdownstream\u201d backwards (i.e. once a photon leaves A toward B it cannot return), mimicking spin\u2010momentum\u2010locking waveguides in an abstract way. This network can be generalized to N hops, illustrating how chiral couplers reduce resource overhead for long\u2010distance teleportation.\n\nVisualization:\n  - Single\u2010photon source at A emits the data qubit into the network.  \n  - Three Bell\u2010pair sources create pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D (each pair source probabilistic).  \n  - At node B: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the incoming data photon from A and one photon of the AB pair \u2192 swaps entanglement to B\u2013C link.  \n  - At node C: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the swapped photon from B\u2013C and one photon of the C\u2013D pair \u2192 final entanglement between A data and D.  \n  - After post\u2010selection, the output qubit emerges at D with the state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9, completing a two\u2010dimensional teleportation channel \u22230\u27e9\u2192\u22230\u27e9, \u22231\u27e9\u2192\u22231\u27e9.\n  - It realizes the quantum network channel that permutes three unknown qubit inputs (at A, B, C) in a cycle\u2014A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A\u2014using only Bell\u2010pair sources, linear optics, and photon detection:\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to implement the channel  \n  \u2223\u03c8_A\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03d5_B\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03c7_C\u27e9  \u21a6  \u2223\u03c7_D\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03c8_E\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03d5_F\u27e9  \nwhere detectors D, E, F sit at nodes A, B, C respectively, and the mapping is the cyclic permutation (A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A).  \n 1. Place three probabilistic Bell-pair sources on links AB, BC, and CA in a ring.  \n 2. At node B, perform a post-selected Bell measurement between the incoming qubit from A and one photon from the AB pair \u2192 swaps A\u2019s state onto the BC link.  \n 3. At node C, perform a Bell measurement between that swapped photon and one from the BC pair \u2192 swaps A\u2019s state onto the CA link.  \n 4. At node A, perform a Bell measurement between that swapped photon and one from the CA pair \u2192 finalizes C\u2192A teleportation.  \n 5. Simultaneously perform the analogous chain of three measurements starting from B\u2192C\u2192A\u2192B and C\u2192A\u2192B\u2192C\u2014i.e. three interlaced teleportation chains\u2014so that after post-selection each node\u2019s input ends up at the next node clockwise.  \n 6. Enforce chirality (unidirectional coupling) by forbidding any Bell source from connecting \u201cagainst\u201d the ring direction using removed_connections.\n\nVisualization of abstract layout:\n  Sources:  \n    S_AB emits to detectors at A' and B'.  \n    S_BC emits to B\u2033 and C'.  \n    S_CA emits to C\u2033 and A\u2033.  \n  Measurements:  \n    M_B on (A', B'), M_C on (B\u2033, C'), M_A on (C\u2033, A\u2033)  \n  Post-selected detections at A (detector D), B (E), C (F) yield the permuted outputs.\n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{'description': 'Chiral cyclic teleportation ring A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192A',\n 'foldername': 'cyclic_chiral_teleport',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',             # overlap with ideal permutation channel\n 'num_anc': 3,                 # one ancilla detector per Bell measurement\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 20,\n 'target_quantum': [\n   # LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm 3 Pytheus-compatible ways to marry \u201cchiral light\u2013matter interaction\u201d and \u201cquantum photonics\u201d in a non-state-generation quantum-network:\n  a) A fully chiral N-hop teleportation chain (repeater) with forbidden backward links.\n  b) A chiral cyclic entanglement-swap ring (permutation channel) around three or more nodes.\n  c) A chiral entanglement-purification plus swapping primitive at a central node\u2014i.e. two imperfect Bell pairs (A\u2013B and B\u2013C) are purified and simultaneously swapped into a single high-fidelity A\u2013C pair via a post-selected CNOT at B, with one-way (chiral) couplings.\nStep 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n  a) Too trivial an extension of standard repeater chains.\n  b) Already covered by cyclic\u2010swap proposals.\n  c) Purification+swapping in one go is a genuinely new network transform for Pytheus: it goes beyond plain entanglement swapping or purification alone, and no Pytheus example covers a joint Bell-pair purification/swap in a chiral setting.\nStep 3: Select (c).\nStep 4: Novelty: This setup implements for the first time in a passive, post-selected linear-optics network a combined entanglement-distillation and entanglement-swapping operation (\u201cpurify-swap\u201d) at a chiral node. It\u2019s a new CPTP map: two noisy Bell channels \u2192 one purified, long-range Bell channel.\nStep 5: Feasibility: Pytheus can build the needed post-selected CNOT from Bell-pair sources, beam splitters, and number-resolving detectors. \u201cremoved_connections\u201d encodes the unidirectional (chiral) edges (A\u2192B and B\u2192C only). No cavities, no feedback, no hybrid entanglement\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s scope.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a target for Pytheus: a \u201cchiral entanglement purification\u2009+\u2009swapping\u201d primitive. Conditioned on the \u201c0\u201d outcome at B, the remaining photons at A and C emerge in a higher-fidelity Bell state.  All couplings are chiral (one-way): photons only flow A\u2192B and B\u2192C (no back-routing), enforced by removed_connections.\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources:\n    S_AB emits to modes A (0) and B_ctrl (1)\n    S_BC emits to modes B_tgt (2) and C (3)\n  Node B:\n    Perform post-selected CNOT(control=mode 1, target=mode 2)\n    Measure mode 2 in the {0,1} basis; The SWAP channel takes an unknown qubit at A and B and outputs them exchanged (A\u2192B_out, B\u2192A_out) purely by post-selected entanglement swapping, with all couplings strictly one-way (chiral).\n\nExplanation:\n\u2022  We encode the SWAP channel by its Choi\u2010vector  \n     |\u03a8_swap\u27e9 = |00;00\u27e9 + |01;10\u27e9 + |10;01\u27e9 + |11;11\u27e9  \n   on four modes [A_in, B_in, A_out, B_out].  \n\u2022  Two probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources: one on link A_in\u2194X, one on link B_in\u2194Y.  \n\u2022  A small linear\u2010optical network and two ancilla detectors at a central station performs a joint four-photon post-selected measurement that heralds successful SWAP.  \n\u2022  Removed_connections forbids any source from sending photons \u201cback\u201d into the wrong output ports\u2014enforcing chirality (e.g. A_in\u2192X\u2192B_out only, B_in\u2192Y\u2192A_out only).  \n\u2022  Upon the two ancilla \u201cclicks,\u201d the two remaining photons emerge at A_out and B_out in the swapped state.\n\nVisualization (logical layout):\n   Single\u2010photon inputs at A_in(0) and B_in(1)\n         \u2502        \u2502\n    BellSource1 \u2500\u253c\u2500 BellSource2\n         \u2502        \u2502\n       LO network & ancilla detectors  \n         \u2193        \u2193\n    A_out(2)   B_out(3)\n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{\n  'description': 'Chiral heralded SWAP channel A\u2194B',\n  'foldername': 'chiral_swap_gate',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n  'edges_tried': 30,\n  'ftol': 1e-6,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',               \n  'num_anc': 2,                    #     "output": "Thought: (\n  Step 1: Brainstorm 3 ways to fuse \u201cchiral light\u2013matter interaction\u201d and \u201cquantum photonics\u201d in a Pytheus-compatible quantum network (no pure state generation):\n    a) A unidirectional N-hop teleportation chain (quantum repeater) with forbidden backward links.\n    b) A chiral cyclic entanglement-swap ring implementing a permutation supermap.\n    c) A chiral \u201cbutterfly\u201d quantum network-coding experiment: two qubits from A\u2192D and B\u2192C cross in a shared network, using entanglement swapping and a multi-port linear-optical measurement at the center.\n  Step 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n    a) Already too close to standard teleportation chains.\n    b) Similar to existing cyclic-swap ideas.\n    c) Network coding is a genuinely new network-level transformation. It does not appear in the explored list, uses only Bell-pair sources, passive linear optics, number-resolving detectors, and removed_connections to enforce chirality. It\u2019s a CPTP supermap, not mere state generation.\n  Step 3: Pick (c).\n  Step 4: This is novel because it\u2019s the first proposed implementation\u2014in purely linear-optical, chiral coupler language\u2014of a quantum \u201cbutterfly\u201d network code: two logical qubits are simultaneously routed across a shared link by a single post-selected measurement at the central node.\n  Step 5: It\u2019s feasible in the Pytheus framework because we can specify the Choi description of the ideal 2-flow channel, use four Bell-pair sources on the butterfly edges, arrange a 4-photon joint linear-optical measurement at the center, and enforce one-way links with removed_connections. No cavities, no hyper-entanglement, no dynamic feedback control\u2014only abstract sources, beamsplitters, and detectors.  \n)\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a proposal for Pytheus: \u201cChiral butterfly quantum network coding.\u201d Two unknown qubits at senders A and B are simultaneously delivered to receivers D and C, crossing over a shared central link by a single entanglement-swapping measurement, with all couplings unidirectional (chiral).\n\nExplanation:\n\u2022 Goal channel \u039b:  \n    (\u03c1_A, \u03c1_B)  \u21a6  (\u03c1_B at C, \u03c1_A at D)  \n  i.e. two flows crossing in a butterfly topology.  \n\u2022 Four probabilistic Bell-pair sources placed on links A\u2013E, B\u2013E, E\u2013C, E\u2013D (E is the central node).  \n\u2022 At node E perform one joint post-selected four-photon linear-optical measurement that implements the network coding transform\u2014combining the two incoming halves of the AB pairs, then re-splitting to CD pairs.  \n\u2022 After heralding on two ancilla detectors at E, the remaining photons at C and D carry the swapped qubits.  \n\u2022 Enforce chirality by forbidding any Bell source to send photons \u201cagainst\u201d the directed butterfly arrows, using removed_connections.\n\nVisualization (logical graph):\n   A\u2500\u2500\u252c         \u250c\u2500\u2500D  \n       \u2572       \u2571  \n        \u25ef\u2500\u2500E\u2500\u2500\u25ef  \n       \u2571       \u2572  \n   B\u2500\u2500\u252c         \u250c\u2500\u2500C  \n  (Bell sources on each edge, joint 4-photon measurement at E)\n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{\n 'description': 'Chiral butterfly quantum network coding A,B\u2192C,D',\n 'foldername': 'chiral_butterfly_qnc',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n 'edges_tried': 50,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',                   # overlap with ideal 2-flow Choi state\n 'num_anc': 2,                        # herald detectors at E\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 30,\n 'target_quantum': [\n   #     "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable Integrated Three-Photon GHZ-Basis Analyzer on Pytheus\n\nAbstract: We implement the target Pytheus-configurable three-photon GHZ-basis analyzer by injecting three unknown photonic qubits and an ancilla Bell pair into a fixed mesh of 50:50 beam splitters augmented with three on-chip electro-optic phase shifters and heralding detectors, thereby unambiguously mapping any incoming triple onto one of the four GHZ basis states. By reprogramming only the EOM voltages\u2014while leaving the linear-optical network unchanged\u2014the same device can project onto the W basis or any rotated three-qubit entangled basis, opening new avenues for adaptive entanglement swapping, secret sharing, and fundamental tests of nonlocality.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement Swapping of 2\u00d72 Toric-Code Logical Qubits via Linear Optics\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate entanglement swapping between two distant logical qubits, each encoded in a minimal 2\u00d72 toric-code patch of four photons at nodes A and D, by performing a post-selected logical Bell measurement on intermediate patches B and C using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, passive linear optics, and ancilla detection. The successful eight-fold coincidence projects detectors 0\u20133 and 12\u201315 onto the unnormalized target quantum state  \n[\"00000000\", \"00001111\", \"11110000\", \"11111111\", \"00110011\", \"00111100\", \"11000011\", \"11001100\"],  \nheralding a fault-tolerant logical Bell pair between A and D without any feed-forward correction.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. This yields a high-fidelity Bell pair between Alice and Bob (the explicit target) within PytHeus\u2019s static linear-optical framework, using two SPDC sources and ancilla detectors without any dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photon-Blockade-Assisted Entanglement Purification of Noisy Bell Pairs\n\nAbstract: We introduce a static linear-optical protocol that combines two probabilistic noisy Bell-pair sources with single-emitter photon-blockade nodes to suppress double-pair emissions and distill the target high-fidelity Bell state |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9=(|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9)/\u221a2. By performing a parity check on one photon from each pair via a 50:50 beam splitter and enforcing \u22641-photon inputs through photon-blockade ancillae, specific heralding detection patterns project the remaining photons onto the purified Bell state within the PyTheus framework.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation of a Single-Photon Qubit through a Coherent Superposition of Markovian and Non-Markovian Channels\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and analyze an optical teleportation experiment in which an unknown target qubit is split into two rails that interact with engineered ancilla chains\u2014one Markovian and one non-Markovian\u2014before being coherently recombined. A Bell-state measurement at Charlie, conditioned on specific click patterns, heralds the successful teleportation of the target quantum to Bob, with fidelity controlled by beam-splitter reflectivities and memory-chain parameters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively. This proof-of-principle experiment doubles qubit throughput in one step without dynamic feed-forward or cavity interfaces, using on-demand SiV\u2013photon entanglement and a bespoke four\u2010click Bell analyzer to herald cross-teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Cyclic Indefinite\u2010Order Entanglement\u2010Swapping Switch for the Three-State Bargmann Invariant\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a static linear-optical network that path-controls a single photon to cyclically superpose three successive Bell\u2013swap orders among unknown qubits A, B, and C, recombining all nine modes in a fixed nine-port interferometer and reading out a binary \u201c+\u201d/\u201c\u2013\u201d outcome. The target is the real part of the three-state Bargmann invariant Re\u2009Tr(\u03c1_A\u2009\u03c1_B\u2009\u03c1_C), whose quantized response statistics directly realize a genuine three-point quantum metric beyond pairwise SWAP tests.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Temporal-Mode Multiplexed Entanglement Swapping with Single Ancilla\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate a static linear-optical station that uses one ancilla Bell pair and a single delay loop to perform two sequential entanglement swaps on unknown qubit pairs arriving in time bins t\u2081 and t\u2082, halving the ancillary resource requirement. The experiment explicitly targets eight two-click detection patterns (four at t\u2081, four at t\u2082) on number-resolving, time-tagging detectors, each pattern heralding a successful swap and showcasing a resonator-inspired temporal coupling strategy for resource-efficient quantum network primitives.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Ancilla-Controlled Programmable Coherent Bell Analyzer\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and simulate a fully coherent measurement supermap\u2014targeting programmable photonic quantum processors\u2014that employs a single Purcell-enhanced on-demand emitter as ancilla (mode 2) to coherently choose between Z- and X-basis Bell measurements on two SPDC-generated photons (modes 0 & 1) within a static linear-optical network. By entangling the control qubit (mode 3) with the Bell-outcome recorded on four ancilla detectors (modes 4\u20137), this design realizes the first programmable photonic Bell analyzer in PyTheus, obviating active switching or teleportation for coherent basis selection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Post-Selected Linear-Optics Teleportation of Wigner-Negative Qutrits in d = 3\n\nAbstract: We design a discrete-variable teleportation channel in dimension d = 3 using a pre-shared probabilistic qutrit Bell pair, four single-photon ancillas, and number-resolving detectors within a linear-optics interferometer to probabilistically teleport any unknown qutrit input.  Leveraging the PytHeus framework, we optimize beam-splitter angles and routing to maximize the teleportation fidelity of representative Wigner-negative test states (\u03a8\u2081,\u03a8\u2082), explicitly targeting the preservation of Wigner function negativity as the primary performance metric.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Using three probabilistic EPR sources, linear-optics routing into two Bell-measurement stations, and post-selection on the control measurement, this experiment realizes the target entanglement-switch quantum switch primitive without state-generation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a proposal for Pytheus to design a \u201cchiral, multi\u2010hop teleportation chain\u201d that implements directional entanglement swapping (i.e. a chiral quantum repeater) between four nodes A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to teleport an unknown qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 from node A to node D by performing sequential entanglement\u2010swapping steps at intermediate nodes B and C, using only probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, single\u2010photon sources, linear optics, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. Chiral (unidirectional) coupling is enforced by forbidding any Bell\u2010pair source from connecting \u201cupstream\u201d to \u201cdownstream\u201d backwards (i.e. once a photon leaves A toward B it cannot return), mimicking spin\u2010momentum\u2010locking waveguides in an abstract way. This network can be generalized to N hops, illustrating how chiral couplers reduce resource overhead for long\u2010distance teleportation.\n\nVisualization:\n  - Single\u2010photon source at A emits the data qubit into the network.  \n  - Three Bell\u2010pair sources create pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D (each pair source probabilistic).  \n  - At node B: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the incoming data photon from A and one photon of the AB pair \u2192 swaps entanglement to B\u2013C link.  \n  - At node C: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the swapped photon from B\u2013C and one photon of the C\u2013D pair \u2192 final entanglement between A data and D.  \n  - After post\u2010selection, the output qubit emerges at D with the state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9, completing a two\u2010dimensional teleportation channel \u22230\u27e9\u2192\u22230\u27e9, \u22231\u27e9\u2192\u22231\u27e9.\n  - No direct source\u2010detector connections backward along the chain, enforced by removed_connections to encode chirality.\n\nConfig Template for Pytheus:\n{'description': 'Chiral 3\u2010hop teleportation chain A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D',\n 'foldername': 'chiral_3hop_teleport',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,    # loosened threshold for post\u2010selection\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',   # count\u2010rate overlap with ideal teleportation channel\n 'num_anc': 4,        # ancilla detectors for two Bell measurements (2 each)\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 20,\n 'target_quantum': ['00','11'],  # ideal identity channel on logical qubit A\u2192D\n 'single_emitters': [0],         # node 0 = A data photon\n 'amplitudes': [],\n 'tries_per_edge': 5,\n 'removed_connections': [\n     # forbid direct A\u2192C, A\u2192D, B\u2192D sources\n     [0,2],[0,3],[1,3]\n ],\n 'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNodes indexing:\n 0 = data photon source at A  \n 1,2,3 = detectors at B (post\u2010Bell measurement), C (post\u2010Bell measurement), D (output)  \n Ancillary detectors correspond to the other two outputs of each Bell\u2010measurement beam\u2010splitter.\n\nThis design can be extended to N hops simply by adding more Bell\u2010pair sources, more \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to enforce one\u2010way propagation, and extra measurement nodes. It realizes the quantum network channel that permutes three unknown qubit inputs (at A, B, C) in a cycle\u2014A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A\u2014using only Bell\u2010pair sources, linear optics, and photon detection:\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to implement the channel  \n  \u2223\u03c8_A\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03d5_B\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03c7_C\u27e9  \u21a6  \u2223\u03c7_D\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03c8_E\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03d5_F\u27e9  \nwhere detectors D, E, F sit at nodes A, B, C respectively, and the mapping is the cyclic permutation (A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A).  \n 1. Place three probabilistic Bell-pair sources on links AB, BC, and CA in a ring.  \n 2. At node B, perform a post-selected Bell measurement between the incoming qubit from A and one photon from the AB pair \u2192 swaps A\u2019s state onto the BC link.  \n 3. At node C, perform a Bell measurement between that swapped photon and one from the BC pair \u2192 swaps A\u2019s state onto the CA link.  \n 4. At node A, perform a Bell measurement between that swapped photon and one from the CA pair \u2192 finalizes C\u2192A teleportation.  \n 5. Simultaneously perform the analogous chain of three measurements starting from B\u2192C\u2192A\u2192B and C\u2192A\u2192B\u2192C\u2014i.e. three interlaced teleportation chains\u2014so that after post-selection each node\u2019s input ends up at the next node clockwise.  \n 6. Enforce chirality (unidirectional coupling) by forbidding any Bell source from connecting \u201cagainst\u201d the ring direction using removed_connections.\n\nVisualization of abstract layout:\n  Sources:  \n    S_AB emits to detectors at A' and B'.  \n    S_BC emits to B\u2033 and C'.  \n    S_CA emits to C\u2033 and A\u2033.  \n  Measurements:  \n    M_B on (A', B'), M_C on (B\u2033, C'), M_A on (C\u2033, A\u2033)  \n  Post-selected detections at A (detector D), B (E), C (F) yield the permuted outputs.\n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{'description': 'Chiral cyclic teleportation ring A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192A',\n 'foldername': 'cyclic_chiral_teleport',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',             # Chirality is enforced by forbidding any Bell source from coupling upstream (removed_connections).\n\nVisualization:\n  1. Control qubit is prepared in superposition of two spatial modes: path0, path1.  \n  2. Data qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 enters both paths.  \n  3. On path0: Bell-pair sources on links AB and BD; post-selected Bell measurement at B, then at D.  \n     On path1: Bell-pair sources on AC and CD; Bell measurement at C, then at D.  \n  4.
