    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable Integrated Three-Photon GHZ-Basis Analyzer on Pytheus\n\nAbstract: We implement the target Pytheus-configurable three-photon GHZ-basis analyzer by injecting three unknown photonic qubits and an ancilla Bell pair into a fixed mesh of 50:50 beam splitters augmented with three on-chip electro-optic phase shifters and heralding detectors, thereby unambiguously mapping any incoming triple onto one of the four GHZ basis states. By reprogramming only the EOM voltages\u2014while leaving the linear-optical network unchanged\u2014the same device can project onto the W basis or any rotated three-qubit entangled basis, opening new avenues for adaptive entanglement swapping, secret sharing, and fundamental tests of nonlocality.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement Swapping of 2\u00d72 Toric-Code Logical Qubits via Linear Optics\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate entanglement swapping between two distant logical qubits, each encoded in a minimal 2\u00d72 toric-code patch of four photons at nodes A and D, by performing a post-selected logical Bell measurement on intermediate patches B and C using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, passive linear optics, and ancilla detection. The successful eight-fold coincidence projects detectors 0\u20133 and 12\u201315 onto the unnormalized target quantum state  \n[\"00000000\", \"00001111\", \"11110000\", \"11111111\", \"00110011\", \"00111100\", \"11000011\", \"11001100\"],  \nheralding a fault-tolerant logical Bell pair between A and D without any feed-forward correction.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. This yields a high-fidelity Bell pair between Alice and Bob (the explicit target) within PytHeus\u2019s static linear-optical framework, using two SPDC sources and ancilla detectors without any dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photon-Blockade-Assisted Entanglement Purification of Noisy Bell Pairs\n\nAbstract: We introduce a static linear-optical protocol that combines two probabilistic noisy Bell-pair sources with single-emitter photon-blockade nodes to suppress double-pair emissions and distill the target high-fidelity Bell state |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9=(|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9)/\u221a2. By performing a parity check on one photon from each pair via a 50:50 beam splitter and enforcing \u22641-photon inputs through photon-blockade ancillae, specific heralding detection patterns project the remaining photons onto the purified Bell state within the PyTheus framework.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation of a Single-Photon Qubit through a Coherent Superposition of Markovian and Non-Markovian Channels\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and analyze an optical teleportation experiment in which an unknown target qubit is split into two rails that interact with engineered ancilla chains\u2014one Markovian and one non-Markovian\u2014before being coherently recombined. A Bell-state measurement at Charlie, conditioned on specific click patterns, heralds the successful teleportation of the target quantum to Bob, with fidelity controlled by beam-splitter reflectivities and memory-chain parameters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively. This proof-of-principle experiment doubles qubit throughput in one step without dynamic feed-forward or cavity interfaces, using on-demand SiV\u2013photon entanglement and a bespoke four\u2010click Bell analyzer to herald cross-teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Cyclic Indefinite\u2010Order Entanglement\u2010Swapping Switch for the Three-State Bargmann Invariant\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a static linear-optical network that path-controls a single photon to cyclically superpose three successive Bell\u2013swap orders among unknown qubits A, B, and C, recombining all nine modes in a fixed nine-port interferometer and reading out a binary \u201c+\u201d/\u201c\u2013\u201d outcome. The target is the real part of the three-state Bargmann invariant Re\u2009Tr(\u03c1_A\u2009\u03c1_B\u2009\u03c1_C), whose quantized response statistics directly realize a genuine three-point quantum metric beyond pairwise SWAP tests.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Temporal-Mode Multiplexed Entanglement Swapping with Single Ancilla\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate a static linear-optical station that uses one ancilla Bell pair and a single delay loop to perform two sequential entanglement swaps on unknown qubit pairs arriving in time bins t\u2081 and t\u2082, halving the ancillary resource requirement. The experiment explicitly targets eight two-click detection patterns (four at t\u2081, four at t\u2082) on number-resolving, time-tagging detectors, each pattern heralding a successful swap and showcasing a resonator-inspired temporal coupling strategy for resource-efficient quantum network primitives.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Ancilla-Controlled Programmable Coherent Bell Analyzer\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and simulate a fully coherent measurement supermap\u2014targeting programmable photonic quantum processors\u2014that employs a single Purcell-enhanced on-demand emitter as ancilla (mode 2) to coherently choose between Z- and X-basis Bell measurements on two SPDC-generated photons (modes 0 & 1) within a static linear-optical network. By entangling the control qubit (mode 3) with the Bell-outcome recorded on four ancilla detectors (modes 4\u20137), this design realizes the first programmable photonic Bell analyzer in PyTheus, obviating active switching or teleportation for coherent basis selection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Post-Selected Linear-Optics Teleportation of Wigner-Negative Qutrits in d = 3\n\nAbstract: We design a discrete-variable teleportation channel in dimension d = 3 using a pre-shared probabilistic qutrit Bell pair, four single-photon ancillas, and number-resolving detectors within a linear-optics interferometer to probabilistically teleport any unknown qutrit input.  Leveraging the PytHeus framework, we optimize beam-splitter angles and routing to maximize the teleportation fidelity of representative Wigner-negative test states (\u03a8\u2081,\u03a8\u2082), explicitly targeting the preservation of Wigner function negativity as the primary performance metric.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a proposal for Pytheus to design a \u201cchiral, multi\u2010hop teleportation chain\u201d that implements directional entanglement swapping (i.e. a chiral quantum repeater) between four nodes A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to teleport an unknown qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 from node A to node D by performing sequential entanglement\u2010swapping steps at intermediate nodes B and C, using only probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, single\u2010photon sources, linear optics, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. Chiral (unidirectional) coupling is enforced by forbidding any Bell\u2010pair source from connecting \u201cupstream\u201d to \u201cdownstream\u201d backwards (i.e. once a photon leaves A toward B it cannot return), mimicking spin\u2010momentum\u2010locking waveguides in an abstract way. This network can be generalized to N hops, illustrating how chiral couplers reduce resource overhead for long\u2010distance teleportation.\n\nVisualization:\n  - Single\u2010photon source at A emits the data qubit into the network.  \n  - Three Bell\u2010pair sources create pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D (each pair source probabilistic).  \n  - At node B: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the incoming data photon from A and one photon of the AB pair \u2192 swaps entanglement to B\u2013C link.  \n  - At node C: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the swapped photon from B\u2013C and one photon of the C\u2013D pair \u2192 final entanglement between A data and D.  \n  - After post\u2010selection, the output qubit emerges at D with the state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9, completing a two\u2010dimensional teleportation channel \u22230\u27e9\u2192\u22230\u27e9, \u22231\u27e9\u2192\u22231\u27e9.\n  - No direct source\u2010detector connections backward along the chain, enforced by removed_connections to encode chirality.\n\nConfig Template for Pytheus:\n{'description': 'Chiral 3\u2010hop teleportation chain A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D',\n 'foldername': 'chiral_3hop_teleport',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,    # loosened threshold for post\u2010selection\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',   # count\u2010rate overlap with ideal teleportation channel\n 'num_anc': 4,        # ancilla detectors for two Bell measurements (2 each)\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 20,\n 'target_quantum': ['00','11'],  # ideal identity channel on logical qubit A\u2192D\n 'single_emitters': [0],         # node 0 = A data photon\n 'amplitudes': [],\n 'tries_per_edge': 5,\n 'removed_connections': [\n     # forbid direct A\u2192C, A\u2192D, B\u2192D sources\n     [0,2],[0,3],[1,3]\n ],\n 'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNodes indexing:\n 0 = data photon source at A  \n 1,2,3 = detectors at B (post\u2010Bell measurement), C (post\u2010Bell measurement), D (output)  \n Ancillary detectors correspond to the other two outputs of each Bell\u2010measurement beam\u2010splitter.\n\nThis design can be extended to N hops simply by adding more Bell\u2010pair sources, more \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to enforce one\u2010way propagation, and extra measurement nodes. The Expert can hand off this abstract target to Pytheus, recover a linear\u2010optics circuit, and write up the first demonstration of a purely chiral, multi\u2010hop entanglement\u2010swapping teleportation network.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This \u201cchiral multi\u2010hop teleportation chain\u201d is just the textbook sequential entanglement\u2010swapping repeater extended with a removed_connections trick to enforce one\u2010way links. It offers no new Bell\u2010measurement primitive or exotic causality superposition beyond standard multi\u2010link swapping (see, e.g., basic two\u2010link entanglement swapping, temporal\u2010mode multiplexing, flux\u2010controlled chiral teleportation routing). It realizes the quantum network channel that permutes three unknown qubit inputs (at A, B, C) in a cycle\u2014A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A\u2014using only Bell\u2010pair sources, linear optics, and photon detection:\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to implement the channel  \n  \u2223\u03c8_A\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03d5_B\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03c7_C\u27e9  \u21a6  \u2223\u03c7_D\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03c8_E\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03d5_F\u27e9  \nwhere detectors D, E, F sit at nodes A, B, C respectively, and the mapping is the cyclic permutation (A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A).  \n 1. Place three probabilistic Bell-pair sources on links AB, BC, and CA in a ring.  \n 2. At node B, perform a post-selected Bell measurement between the incoming qubit from A and one photon from the AB pair \u2192 swaps A\u2019s state onto the BC link.  \n 3. At node C, perform a Bell measurement between that swapped photon and one from the BC pair \u2192 swaps A\u2019s state onto the CA link.  \n 4. At node A, perform a Bell measurement between that swapped photon and one from the CA pair \u2192 finalizes C\u2192A teleportation.  \n 5. Simultaneously perform the analogous chain of three measurements starting from B\u2192C\u2192A\u2192B and C\u2192A\u2192B\u2192C\u2014i.e. three interlaced teleportation chains\u2014so that after post-selection each node\u2019s input ends up at the next node clockwise.  \n 6. Enforce chirality (unidirectional coupling) by forbidding any Bell source from connecting \u201cagainst\u201d the ring direction using removed_connections.\n\nVisualization of abstract layout:\n  Sources:  \n    S_AB emits to detectors at A' and B'.  \n    S_BC emits to B\u2033 and C'.  \n    S_CA emits to C\u2033 and A\u2033.  \n  Measurements:  \n    M_B on (A', B'), M_C on (B\u2033, C'), M_A on (C\u2033, A\u2033)  \n  Post-selected detections at A (detector D), B (E), C (F) yield the permuted outputs.\n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{'description': 'Chiral cyclic teleportation ring A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192A',\n 'foldername': 'cyclic_chiral_teleport',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',             # overlap with ideal permutation channel\n 'num_anc': 3,                 # one ancilla detector per Bell measurement\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 20,\n 'target_quantum': [\n   # Since this idea already appears in the shared list, the new proposal adds only a removed_connections constraint for chirality and offers no genuine new measurement primitive or nontrivial coherence effect.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This cyclic teleportation scheme duplicates the \u201cThree\u2010Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring\u2010Exchange\u201d from the ensemble list. To be novel, you must go beyond standard sequential Bell\u2010swap permutations\u2014introducing a new non\u2010trivial supermap, causal superposition, or a higher\u2010dimensional network effect\u2014rather than simply enforcing directional links via graph constraints.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a proposal for Pytheus to design a \u201cchiral quantum switch\u201d that coherently superposes two teleportation orders (A\u2192B\u2192D vs. A\u2192C\u2192D), controlled by a path qubit:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to implement the quantum SWITCH supermap which, on input an unknown qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 at A and a control qubit \u22230\u27e9+\u22231\u27e9 (path\u2010encoded), routes the data through two Bell-swap channels in superposition of order:\n  if ctrl=0: teleport A\u2192B then B\u2192D  \n  if ctrl=1: teleport A\u2192C then C\u2192D  \nAfter recombining the paths, the output at D emerges entangled with the control, realizing the coherent superposition of two causal orders. Chirality is enforced by forbidding any Bell source from coupling upstream (removed_connections).\n\nVisualization:\n  1. Control qubit is prepared in superposition of two spatial modes: path0, path1.  \n  2. Data qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 enters both paths.  \n  3. On path0: Bell-pair sources on links AB and BD; post-selected Bell measurement at B, then at D.  \n     On path1: Bell-pair sources on AC and CD; Bell measurement at C, then at D.  \n  4. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party.     "output": "Thought:\n Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible chiral\u2013quantum\u2010photonics network ideas:\n   a) A unidirectional N-hop teleportation chain (standard repeater).\n   b) A chiral cyclic entanglement-swap ring (permutation channel).\n   c) A chiral \u201c3-switch\u201d supermap: indefinite causal order of three entanglement-swapping operations controlled by a path-encoded qutrit.\n Step 2: Check novelty/feasibility:\n   a) Too close to known repeaters.\n   b) Already explored cyclic swaps.\n   c) The 3-switch is genuinely new in that no Pytheus example has tackled a three-operation indefinite causal-order network. It uses only abstract Bell-pair sources, linear optics, number-resolving detectors, and \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to encode chiral one-way links.\n Step 3: Pick (c).\n Step 4: Novelty: It implements for the first time a three-operation quantum SWITCH\u2014coherently superposing the order in which three entanglement-swapping nodes (B,C,D) act on a data qubit\u2014exploring higher-order causal non-separability in a photonic network.\n Step 5: Feasibility: Pytheus can optimize an abstract circuit with a three-port path-encoded qutrit control, three Bell-pair sources on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D, and three post-selected Bell measurements at B, C, D\u2014no cavities, no dynamic feedback, no hybrid entanglement, only linear optics, sources, detectors, and removed_connections to enforce chirality.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a proposal for Pytheus to design a \u201cchiral 3-switch entanglement-swapping network,\u201d realizing an indefinite causal order supermap over three entanglement-swap operations:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to teleport an unknown qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 from A to E by three successive entanglement-swapping nodes B, C, D\u2014but in a superposition of all 3!\u2009=\u20096 possible orders. A path-encoded qutrit control at A picks the order coherently. When all three Bell measurements succeed (post-selected), the photon emerges at E still carrying \u2223\u03c8\u27e9, with the control qutrit entangled to the order, evidencing indefinite causal structure. All photon links are enforced one-way (\u201cchiral\u201d) by removed_connections.\n\nLogical layout:\n  A: emits data \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 and control qutrit (3-mode splitter)  \n   \u2514\u2192 path i \u2192 Bell-swap at node \u03c0(i,1), then \u03c0(i,2), then \u03c0(i,3)  \n  Links: Bell sources on AB, BC, CD  \n  Measurements: at B, C, D perform post-selected Bell measurements  \n  E: recombine control arms \u2192 output \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 at E and control readout  \n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{\n 'description': 'Chiral 3-switch entanglement-swapping supermap A\u2192E',\n 'foldername': 'chiral_3switch_swap',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 50,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',               # overlap with ideal 3-switch Choi process\n 'num_anc': 6,                    # two ancilla detectors per Bell measurement\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 30,\n 'target_quantum': [\n   # 9-mode Choi basis: control_qutrit(3) \u00d7 data_in(2) \u2192 control_qutrit(3) \u00d7 data_out(2)\n   # Flattened into 3+1+3+1=8 photons across 9 modes; expert will enumerate the 12 nonzero terms.\n   # Example placeholders:\n   '000000000','001001001','002002002',\n   '100100100','101101101','102102102',\n   '200200200','201201201','202202202'\n ],\n 'single_emitters': [0],          # node 0 = combined data+control source at A\n 'amplitudes': [],\n 'tries_per_edge': 5,\n 'removed_connections': [\n   # enforce chirality: no backward/cross couplings between Bell sources and measurement ports\n   [1,8],[2,7],[3,6]\n ],\n 'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNode indexing guide (for the Expert):\n 0 = three-port qutrit splitter input at A  \n 1\u20133 = outputs of Bell sources AB, BC, CD feeding into measurements  \n 4\u20139 = ancilla detectors at B, C, D (two each)  \n10 = final recombined control port \u2192 E data output  \n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 N-switch: extend to N entanglement-swap nodes with an N-port control.  \n \u2022 Study causal non-separability measures, success probability vs. resource scaling under chiral constraints.\n\nThis target asks Pytheus to find the optimal linear-optical network realizing the first chiral 3-switch supermap\u2014uniting chiral quantum\u2010photonics couplings with higher-order causal superposition via entanglement swapping."

{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable Integrated Three-Photon GHZ-Basis Analyzer on Pytheus\n\nAbstract: We implement the target Pytheus-configurable three-photon GHZ-basis analyzer by injecting three unknown photonic qubits and an ancilla Bell pair into a fixed mesh of 50:50 beam splitters augmented with three on-chip electro-optic phase shifters and heralding detectors, thereby unambiguously mapping any incoming triple onto one of the four GHZ basis states. By reprogramming only the EOM voltages\u2014while leaving the linear-optical network unchanged\u2014the same device can project onto the W basis or any rotated three-qubit entangled basis, opening new avenues for adaptive entanglement swapping, secret sharing, and fundamental tests of nonlocality.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement Swapping of 2\u00d72 Toric-Code Logical Qubits via Linear Optics\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate entanglement swapping between two distant logical qubits, each encoded in a minimal 2\u00d72 toric-code patch of four photons at nodes A and D, by performing a post-selected logical Bell measurement on intermediate patches B and C using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, passive linear optics, and ancilla detection. By mixing only the \u201cmiddle\u201d modes with two ancilla photons through beam splitters and phase shifters\u2014and detecting exactly one photon on each ancilla detector\u2014this passive linear-optical protocol achieves the desired entanglement shift without active feedback or cavities and plugs directly into the Pytheus toolkit.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). Chiral (unidirectional) coupling is enforced by forbidding any Bell\u2010pair source from connecting \u201cupstream\u201d to \u201cdownstream\u201d backwards (i.e. once a photon leaves A toward B it cannot return), mimicking spin\u2010momentum\u2010locking waveguides in an abstract way. This network can be generalized to N hops, illustrating how chiral couplers reduce resource overhead for long\u2010distance teleportation.\n\nVisualization:\n  - Single\u2010photon source at A emits the data qubit into the network.  \n  - Three Bell\u2010pair sources create pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D (each pair source probabilistic).  \n  - At node B: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the incoming data photon from A and one photon of the AB pair \u2192 swaps entanglement to B\u2013C link.  \n  - At node C: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the swapped photon from B\u2013C and one photon of the C\u2013D pair \u2192 final entanglement between A data and D.  \n  - After post\u2010selection, the output qubit emerges at D with the state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9, completing a two\u2010dimensional teleportation channel \u22230\u27e9\u2192\u22230\u27e9, \u22231\u27e9\u2192\u22231\u27e9.\n  - Place three probabilistic Bell-pair sources on links AB, BC, and CA in a ring.  \n 2. At node B, perform a post-selected Bell measurement between the incoming qubit from A and one photon from the AB pair \u2192 swaps A\u2019s state onto the BC link.  \n 3. At node C, perform a Bell measurement between that swapped photon and one from the BC pair \u2192 swaps A\u2019s state onto the CA link.  \n 4. At node A, perform a Bell measurement between that swapped photon and one from the CA pair \u2192 finalizes C\u2192A teleportation.  \n 5. Simultaneously perform the analogous chain of three measurements starting from B\u2192C\u2192A\u2192B and C\u2192A\u2192B\u2192C\u2014i.e. three interlaced teleportation chains\u2014so that after post-selection each node\u2019s input ends up at the next node clockwise.  \n 6. After the two swap stages in each arm, the two resulting photons recombine on a second 50:50 beam splitter.  \n4. A path-encoded qutrit control at A picks the order coherently. At node A perform one joint post-selected four-photon linear-optical measurement (a generalized Bell\u2010swap measurement on the input qubit plus one photon from each Bell pair).  Outcome \u201csuccess\u201d is heralded by two ancilla detectors.  \n3. Conditioned on that herald, the remaining photon halves at B, C, D form the three quantum shares of the secret.  \n4. Enforce chirality by forbidding any Bell source to send photons backward or cross-link (e.g. no A\u2013B source to C or D\u2019s measurement ports), via the removed_connections keyword.\n\nVisualization:\n   [Input qubit at A]\u2500\u2500\u252c\u2500\u2500Bell_AB\u2500\u2500\u2510  \n                       \u2502            \u2502  \n                       \u2502  Joint      \u251c\u2500 ancilla detections  \n                       \u2502 measurement \u2502  \n                       \u2502            \u2502  \n   Bell_AC\u2500\u2500\u2510          \u2514\u2500\u2500Bell_AD\u2500\u2500\u253c  \n            \u2502                      \u2502  \n           B_share                C_share  \n                                 D_share  \n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{'description': 'Chiral (2,3) quantum secret sharing A\u2192{B,C,D}',\n 'foldername': 'chiral_2_3_secret_sharing',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'ftol': 1e-06,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',                #     "output": "Here is a proposal for Pytheus to explore _chiral entanglement percolation_ in a small\u2010world, directed four\u2010node network.  Rather than simply teleporting or swapping along a line, we introduce extra \u201cshortcut\u201d links and enforce strict one\u2010way (chiral) couplings, then ask Pytheus to find the optimal pattern of Bell\u2010swap measurements at the intermediate nodes to maximize the probability of generating a Bell pair between the end nodes 0 and 3.\n\nExplanation:\n\u2022 Network graph: nodes 0\u21921\u21922\u21923 (a directed line) plus two directed \u201csmall\u2010world\u201d shortcuts 0\u21922 and 1\u21923.  \n\u2022 Each directed edge is realized by an abstract probabilistic Bell\u2010pair source.  \n\u2022 At nodes 1 and 2 we perform post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurements to \u201cswap\u201d entanglement along whichever path (or combination of paths) Pytheus finds best.  By comparing success probabilities with and without shortcuts, one probes how chirality and small\u2010world links enhance long\u2010distance entanglement percolation.  \n\u2022 Strict chirality is enforced by forbidding any source to send photons opposite to the arrow of the edges, via removed_connections.  \n\u2022 The target is a two\u2010qubit Bell\u2010state \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 between detectors at node 0 and node 3.  \n\u2022 This setup immediately generalizes to larger directed small\u2010world graphs, random\u2010removal studies, and percolation thresholds.\n\nConfiguration template for Pytheus (to be adapted by the Expert):\n\n{\n  'description': 'Chiral small\u2010world entanglement percolation on 4 nodes',\n  'foldername':    'chiral_sw_percolation_4',\n  'bulk_thr':      0.01,\n  'edges_tried':   30,\n  'ftol':          1e-6,\n  'loss_func':     'cr',                # maximize count\u2010rate overlap with Bell(0,3)\n  'num_anc':       4,                   # two ancillas at node 1 swap + two at node 2 swap\n  'num_pre':       1,\n  'optimizer':     'L-BFGS-B',\n  'imaginary':     False,\n  'safe_hist':     True,\n  'samples':       20,\n  'target_quantum':['00','11'],         # ideal Bell at nodes 0 & 3\n  'single_emitters': [],\n  'amplitudes':    [],\n  'tries_per_edge':5,\n  'removed_connections': [\n      # forbid any source from routing photons backward against the directed edges:\n      # no 1\u21920, 2\u21921, 3\u21922, 2\u21920 (no backward on shortcut), 3\u21921\n      [1,0],[2,1],[3,2],[2,0],[3,1]\n  ],\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNode indexing (example):\n \u2022 Sources: five abstract Bell\u2010pair sources on edges (0\u21921), (1\u21922), (2\u21923), (0\u21922), (1\u21923).  \n \u2022 Detectors:  \n    \u2013 D0 and D3 are the two final detectors at node 0 and node 3 whose coincidence signals the Bell pair.  \n    \u2013 At node 1 two ancilla detectors herald the Bell swap on whichever incoming links are used.  \n    \u2013 At node 2 two ancilla detectors herald the second swap.  \n\nWhy this is interesting and novel:\n\u2022 Networks & foundational physics: It studies _directed_ percolation of entanglement in small\u2010world graphs\u2014a topic so far unexplored experimentally.  \n\u2022 Chiral light\u2013matter interplay: By enforcing one\u2010way connectivity (\u201cchirality\u201d) at the level of abstract sources, we probe how directionality enhances or restricts entanglement distribution.  \n\u2022 Quantum\u2010photonic toolbox only: Uses probabilistic Bell pairs, linear optics, number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014exactly what Pytheus can optimize.  \n\u2022 Generalization: Extend to N nodes, random\u2010removal of shortcuts, and measure percolation thresholds and robustness.  \n\nThis target invites Pytheus to tackle a new class of _quantum network percolation_ problem with chiral constraints, yielding both a rich family of experiments and fresh theory on directed entanglement routing."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. Modularly extendable to N hops.\n  b) A cyclic entanglement\u2010swapping ring across three (or four) nodes using chiral couplers: generate Bell pairs on each edge of a ring, perform Bell measurements at each vertex to \u201cswap\u201d entanglement around the loop in a directional fashion, exploring topological aspects of chiral networks.\n  c) A post\u2010selected, chiral \u201cquantum router\u201d that conditionally swaps two photonic qubits between two output ports based on the path\u2010encoded control qubit, implemented by directional beam\u2010splitter network\u2014i.e. a heralded CSWAP in a chiral geometry.\nStep 2: Quick novelty/obstacle check:\n  a) Multi\u2010hop teleportation: extends two\u2010node swapping to N\u2010node directional chain\u2014novel in ring/examples. No cavities; uses removed_connections to enforce one\u2010way links. It introduces a family of N\u2010hop chiral quantum repeaters implementable in free\u2010space or integrated photonics, with resource\u2010scaling advantages from directed couplings.\nStep 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because it only requires abstract Bell\u2010pair sources and single\u2010photon input, linear optics, photodetection, and \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to enforce one\u2010way (chiral) links\u2014no cavities, no feedback, no hybrid entanglement, no state generation target, just a targeted two\u2010dimensional teleportation channel \u201c|0>\u2192|0> and |1>\u2192|1>\u201d across four nodes. \nAction: final answer\nAction Input: \nHere is a proposal for Pytheus to design a \u201cchiral, multi\u2010hop teleportation chain\u201d that implements directional entanglement swapping (i.e. a chiral quantum repeater) between four nodes A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to teleport an unknown qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 from node A to node D by performing sequential entanglement\u2010swapping steps at intermediate nodes B and C, using only probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, single\u2010photon sources, linear optics, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. Chiral (unidirectional) coupling is enforced by forbidding any Bell\u2010pair source from connecting \u201cupstream\u201d to \u201cdownstream\u201d backwards (i.e. once a photon leaves A toward B it cannot return), mimicking spin\u2010momentum\u2010locking waveguides in an abstract way. This network can be generalized to N hops, illustrating how chiral couplers reduce resource overhead for long\u2010distance teleportation.\n\nVisualization:\n  - Single\u2010photon source at A emits the data qubit into the network.  \n  - Three Bell\u2010pair sources create pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D (each pair source probabilistic).  \n  - At node B: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the incoming data photon from A and one photon of the AB pair \u2192 swaps entanglement to B\u2013C link.  \n  - At node C: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the swapped photon from B\u2013C and one photon of the C\u2013D pair \u2192 final entanglement between A data and D.  \n  - After post\u2010selection, the output qubit emerges at D with the state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9, completing a two\u2010dimensional teleportation channel \u22230\u27e9\u2192\u22230\u27e9, \u22231\u27e9\u2192\u22231\u27e9.\n  - It\u2019s a coherent supermap on three channel topologies, purely linear\u2010optical with Bell-pairs and single photons, chiral via \u201cremoved_connections.\u201d  \n  Step 3: Select (c).\n  Step 4: Novelty: This implements, for the first time, a coherent superposition of three chiral teleportation networks\u2014(i) direct photonic transmission A\u2192D, (ii) entanglement swapping A\u2192B\u2192D, and (iii) entanglement swapping A\u2192C\u2192D\u2014in one static circuit. No prior Pytheus example has built a passive, teleportation-based router with chiral enforcement.  \n  \u2022 Feasible? Requires only abstract Bell-pair sources, one single-photon data source, linear optics, number-resolving detectors, and \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to forbid backward links.  \n  \u2022 Transformation? It implements a two-outcome teleportation channel, a genuine network primitive (routing), not mere state generation.  \nStep 3: Choose (c).\nStep 4: Novelty: This is the first purely passive, post-selected, chiral teleportation router\u2014route-the-fly of a photonic qubit\u2014without active modulators or feedback, illustrating how chiral coupler constraints can be used for built-in routing.  \nStep 5: Feasibility: Pytheus can optimize two probabilistic Bell sources (H\u2013B and H\u2013C), one single-photon emitter at A, a small beamsplitter network at H combining the data photon and the two Bell halves, and two ancilla detectors whose \u201cwhich-click\u201d pattern heralds teleportation to B or C. \u201cremoved_connections\u201d enforce that no source can send photons upstream or cross-feed the wrong detector, fully within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optical, no-feedback model.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a target for Pytheus: \u201cChiral teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}.\u201d  It implements a two-outcome teleportation channel in a strictly one-way (chiral) network:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to teleport an unknown qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 at node A to either receiver B or receiver C, with the choice made passively by which heralding detector clicks at a central hub H.  No active modulators or classical feedback are used\u2014just two Bell-pair sources, a small static linear-optical circuit, and number-resolving detectors.  All photon links are enforced one way (A\u2192H\u2192B or A\u2192H\u2192C) via removed_connections.\n\nProtocol:\n1. Single-photon source at A emits the data qubit into mode A_data.  \n2. Two probabilistic Bell-pair sources:  \n   \u2022 S_HB emits one half to hub mode H_B and one half to receiver B;  \n   \u2022 S_HC emits one half to hub mode H_C and one half to receiver C.  \n3. At hub H, a three-mode linear-optical interferometer combines A_data, H_B, and H_C.  Two ancilla, number-resolving detectors D_B and D_C monitor this block.  \n   \u2022 If D_B clicks and D_C does not \u2192 data qubit is teleported to receiver B (in the leftover photon at B).  \n   \u2022 If D_C clicks and D_B does not \u2192 data qubit is teleported to receiver C.  \n   \u2022 Other patterns = failure (discard).  \n4. \u201cremoved_connections\u201d forbids any source from sending photons backward or cross-coupling (e.g. S_HB cannot feed H_C, S_HC cannot feed H_B, and neither can send to A_data).\n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{\n  'description': 'Chiral teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}',\n  'foldername': 'chiral_teleportation_router',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n  'edges_tried': 30,\n  'ftol': 1e-6,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',              # maximize fidelity of the two-outcome teleportation channel\n  'num_anc': 2,                   # detectors D_B, D_C at hub\n  'num_pre': 1,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'imaginary': False,\n  'safe_hist': True,\n  'samples': 20,\n  'target_quantum': [\n    # Choi basis for the channel: input qubit at A maps to B when outcome=0 and to C when outcome=1\n    # Represented as the 4 nonzero 4-qubit amplitudes of the classical-quantum Choi state\n    '0000','0110','1001','1111'\n  ],\n  'single_emitters': [0],         # node 0 = data source A\n  'amplitudes': [],\n  'tries_per_edge': 5,\n  'removed_connections': [\n    [1,3],  # forbid S_HB\u2019s hub output (mode 1) \u2192 detector D_C (mode 3)\n    [2,2]   # forbid S_HC\u2019s hub output (mode 2) \u2192 detector D_B (mode 2)\n  ],\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNode indexing (example for Expert):\n 0 = data photon at A  \n 1 = hub mode from S_HB  \n 2 = hub mode from S_HC  \n 3 = heralding detector D_B  \n 4 = heralding detector D_C  \n 5 = B\u2019s output detector (teleported qubit)  \n 6 = C\u2019s output detector  \n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Extend to N outputs (A\u2192{B\u2081,\u2026,B_N}) with an N-port interferometer and N Bell pairs.  \n \u2022 Add a path-encoded quantum or classical control to bias routing.  \n \u2022 Study success probability vs. N under chiral coupling constraints.\n\nThis experiment leverages chiral (one-way) connectivity, passive linear optics, and post-selected entanglement swapping to realize a genuine routing supermap\u2014an entirely new quantum-network primitive for quantum photonics."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable Integrated Three-Photon GHZ-Basis Analyzer on Pytheus\n\nAbstract: We implement the target Pytheus-configurable three-photon GHZ-basis analyzer by injecting three unknown photonic qubits and an ancilla Bell pair into a fixed mesh of 50:50 beam splitters augmented with three on-chip electro-optic phase shifters and heralding detectors, thereby unambiguously mapping any incoming triple onto one of the four GHZ basis states. By reprogramming only the EOM voltages\u2014while leaving the linear-optical network unchanged\u2014the same device can project onto the W basis or any rotated three-qubit entangled basis, opening new avenues for adaptive entanglement swapping, secret sharing, and fundamental tests of nonlocality.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement Swapping of 2\u00d72 Toric-Code Logical Qubits via Linear Optics\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate entanglement swapping between two distant logical qubits, each encoded in a minimal 2\u00d72 toric-code patch of four photons at nodes A and D, by performing a post-selected logical Bell measurement on intermediate patches B and C using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, passive linear optics, and ancilla detection. This yields a high-fidelity Bell pair between Alice and Bob (the explicit target) within PytHeus\u2019s static linear-optical framework, using two SPDC sources and ancilla detectors without any dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photon-Blockade-Assisted Entanglement Purification of Noisy Bell Pairs\n\nAbstract: We introduce a static linear-optical protocol that combines two probabilistic noisy Bell-pair sources with single-emitter photon-blockade nodes to suppress double-pair emissions and distill the target high-fidelity Bell state |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9=(|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9)/\u221a2. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. Chiral (unidirectional) coupling is enforced by forbidding any Bell\u2010pair source from connecting \u201cupstream\u201d to \u201cdownstream\u201d backwards (i.e. once a photon leaves A toward B it cannot return), mimicking spin\u2010momentum\u2010locking waveguides in an abstract way. A path-encoded qutrit control at A picks the order coherently. When all three Bell measurements succeed (post-selected), the photon emerges at E still carrying \u2223\u03c8\u27e9, with the control qutrit entangled to the order, evidencing indefinite causal structure. All photon links are enforced one-way (\u201cchiral\u201d) by removed_connections.\n\nLogical layout:\n  A: emits data \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 and control qutrit (3-mode splitter)  \n   \u2514\u2192 path i \u2192 Bell-swap at node \u03c0(i,1), then \u03c0(i,2), then \u03c0(i,3)  \n  Links: Bell sources on AB, BC, CD  \n  Measurements: at B, C, D perform post-selected Bell measurements  \n  E: recombine control arms \u2192 output \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 at E and control readout  \n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{\n 'description': 'Chiral 3-switch entanglement-swapping supermap A\u2192E',\n 'foldername': 'chiral_3switch_swap',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 50,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',               # overlap with ideal 3-switch Choi process\n 'num_anc': 6,                    # two ancilla detectors per Bell measurement\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 30,\n 'target_quantum': [\n   # 9-mode Choi basis: control_qutrit(3) \u00d7 data_in(2) \u2192 control_qutrit(3) \u00d7 data_out(2)\n   # Flattened into 3+1+3+1=8 photons across 9 modes; expert will enumerate the 12 nonzero terms.\n   # Example placeholders:\n   '000000000','001001001','002002002',\n   '100100100','101101101','102102102',\n   '200200200','201201201','202202202'\n ],\n 'single_emitters': [0],          # node 0 = combined data+control source at A\n 'amplitudes': [],\n 'tries_per_edge': 5,\n 'removed_connections': [\n   # enforce chirality: no backward/cross couplings between Bell sources and measurement ports\n   [1,8],[2,7],[3,6]\n ],\n 'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNode indexing guide (for the Expert):\n 0 = three-port qutrit splitter input at A  \n 1\u20133 = outputs of Bell sources AB, BC, CD feeding into measurements  \n 4\u20139 = ancilla detectors at B, C, D (two each)  \n10 = final recombined control port \u2192 E data output  \n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 N-switch: extend to N entanglement-swap nodes with an N-port control.  \n \u2022 Study causal non-separability measures, success probability vs. resource scaling under chiral constraints.\n\nThis target asks Pytheus to find the optimal linear-optical network realizing the first chiral 3-switch supermap\u2014uniting chiral quantum\u2010photonics couplings with higher-order causal superposition via entanglement swapping.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed 3-switch entanglement\u2013swapping channel\u2014coherently superposing all six orders of three sequential Bell swaps to teleport from A to E\u2014is essentially the same indefinite-order swapping supermap already in the ensemble (see \u201cCyclic Indefinite-Order Entanglement-Swapping Switch for the Three-State Bargmann Invariant\u201d). Enforcing chirality via removed_connections does not introduce a new measurement primitive or higher-order supermap beyond that known cyclic 3-switch.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This idea duplicates the existing three-swap indefinite-order switch protocols. To be novel at the PRL level, you need a genuinely new quantum-network primitive\u2014such as a higher-dimensional supermap, a new non-unitary measurement architecture, or a truly distinct causal/coherence effect\u2014rather than another chiral re-wiring of an already studied switch.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a target for Pytheus: \u201cChiral teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}.\u201d  It implements a two-outcome teleportation channel in a strictly one-way (chiral) network:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to teleport an unknown qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 at node A to either receiver B or receiver C, with the choice made passively by which heralding detector clicks at a central hub H.  No active modulators or classical feedback are used\u2014just two Bell-pair sources, a small static linear-optical circuit, and number-resolving detectors.  All photon links are enforced one way (A\u2192H\u2192B or A\u2192H\u2192C) via removed_connections.\n\nProtocol:\n1. Single-photon source at A emits the data qubit into mode A_data.  \n2. Two probabilistic Bell-pair sources:  \n   \u2022 S_HB emits one half to hub mode H_B and one half to receiver B;  \n   \u2022 S_HC emits one half to hub mode H_C and one half to receiver C.  \n3. At hub H, a three-mode linear-optical interferometer combines A_data, H_B, and H_C.  Two ancilla, number-resolving detectors D_B and D_C monitor this block.  \n   \u2022 If D_B clicks and D_C does not \u2192 data qubit is teleported to receiver B (in the leftover photon at B).  \n   \u2022 If D_C clicks and D_B does not \u2192 data qubit is teleported to receiver C.  \n   \u2022 Other patterns = failure (discard).  \n4. \u201cremoved_connections\u201d forbids any source from sending photons backward or cross-coupling (e.g. S_HB cannot feed H_C, S_HC cannot feed H_B, and neither can send to A_data).\n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{\n  'description': 'Chiral teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}',\n  'foldername': 'chiral_teleportation_router',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n  'edges_tried': 30,\n  'ftol': 1e-6,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',              # maximize fidelity of the two-outcome teleportation channel\n  'num_anc': 2,                   # detectors D_B, D_C at hub\n  'num_pre': 1,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'imaginary': False,\n  'safe_hist': True,\n  'samples': 20,\n  'target_quantum': [\n    # node 0 = data source A\n  'amplitudes': [],\n  'tries_per_edge': 5,\n  'removed_connections': [\n    [1,3],  # forbid S_HB\u2019s hub output (mode 1) \u2192 detector D_C (mode 3)\n    [2,2]   # forbid S_HC\u2019s hub output (mode 2) \u2192 detector D_B (mode 2)\n  ],\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNode indexing (example for Expert):\n 0 = data photon at A  \n 1 = hub mode from S_HB  \n 2 = hub mode from S_HC  \n 3 = heralding detector D_B  \n 4 = heralding detector D_C  \n 5 = B\u2019s output detector (teleported qubit)  \n 6 = C\u2019s output detector  \n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Extend to N outputs (A\u2192{B\u2081,\u2026,B_N}) with an N-port interferometer and N Bell pairs.  \n \u2022 Add a path-encoded quantum or classical control to bias routing.  \n \u2022 Study success probability vs. N under chiral coupling constraints.\n\nThis experiment leverages chiral (one-way) connectivity, passive linear optics, and post-selected entanglement swapping to realize a genuine routing supermap\u2014an entirely new quantum-network primitive for quantum photonics.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: This \u201cchiral teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}\u201d is essentially a passive dual\u2010destination teleportation switch already proposed in the ensemble (\u201cDual\u2010Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\u201d). At node A perform one joint post-selected four-photon linear-optical measurement (a generalized Bell\u2010swap measurement on the input qubit plus one photon from each Bell pair).  Outcome \u201csuccess\u201d is heralded by two ancilla detectors.  \n3. Conditioned on that herald, the remaining photon halves at B, C, D form the three quantum shares of the secret.  \n4. Enforce chirality by forbidding any Bell source to send photons backward or cross-link (e.g. no A\u2013B source to C or D\u2019s measurement ports), via the removed_connections keyword.\n\nVisualization:\n   [Input qubit at A]\u2500\u2500\u252c\u2500\u2500Bell_AB\u2500\u2500\u2510  \n                       \u2502            \u2502  \n                       \u2502  Joint      \u251c\u2500 ancilla detections  \n                       \u2502 measurement \u2502  \n                       \u2502            \u2502  \n   Bell_AC\u2500\u2500\u2510          \u2514\u2500\u2500Bell_AD\u2500\u2500\u253c  \n            \u2502                      \u2502  \n           B_share                C_share  \n                                 D_share  \n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{'description': 'Chiral (2,3) quantum secret sharing A\u2192{B,C,D}',\n 'foldername': 'chiral_2_3_secret_sharing',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'ftol': 1e-06,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',                # No prior Pytheus example has built a passive, teleportation-based router with chiral enforcement.  \n  \u2022 Feasible? It implements a two-outcome teleportation channel, a genuine network primitive (routing), not mere state generation.  \nStep 3: Choose (c).\nStep 4: Novelty: This is the first purely passive, post-selected, chiral teleportation router\u2014route-the-fly of a photonic qubit\u2014without active modulators or feedback, illustrating how chiral coupler constraints can be used for built-in routing.  \nStep 5: Feasibility: Pytheus can optimize two probabilistic Bell sources (H\u2013B and H\u2013C), one single-photon emitter at A, a small beamsplitter network at H combining the data photon and the two Bell halves, and two ancilla detectors whose \u201cwhich-click\u201d pattern heralds teleportation to B or C. \u201cremoved_connections\u201d enforce that no source can send photons upstream or cross-feed the wrong detector, fully within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optical, no-feedback model.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a target for Pytheus: \u201cChiral teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}.\u201d  It implements a two-outcome teleportation channel in a strictly one-way (chiral) network:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to teleport an unknown qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 at node A to either receiver B or receiver C, with the choice made passively by which heralding detector clicks at a central hub H.  No active modulators or classical feedback are used\u2014just two Bell-pair sources, a small static linear-optical circuit, and number-resolving detectors.  All photon links are enforced one way (A\u2192H\u2192B or A\u2192H\u2192C) via removed_connections.\n\nProtocol:\n1. Single-photon source at A emits the data qubit into mode A_data.  \n2. Two probabilistic Bell-pair sources:  \n   \u2022 S_HB emits one half to hub mode H_B and one half to receiver B;  \n   \u2022 S_HC emits one half to hub mode H_C and one half to receiver C.  \n3. At hub H, a three-mode linear-optical interferometer combines A_data, H_B, and H_C.  Two ancilla, number-resolving detectors D_B and D_C monitor this block.  \n   \u2022 If D_B clicks and D_C does not \u2192 data qubit is teleported to receiver B (in the leftover photon at B).  \n   \u2022 If D_C clicks and D_B does not \u2192 data qubit is teleported to receiver C.  \n   \u2022 Other patterns = failure (discard).  \n4. \u201cremoved_connections\u201d forbids any source from sending photons backward or cross-coupling (e.g. S_HB cannot feed H_C, S_HC cannot feed H_B, and neither can send to A_data).\n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{\n  'description': 'Chiral teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}',\n  'foldername': 'chiral_teleportation_router',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n  'edges_tried': 30,\n  'ftol': 1e-6,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',              # maximize fidelity of the two-outcome teleportation channel\n  'num_anc': 2,                   # detectors D_B, D_C at hub\n  'num_pre': 1,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'imaginary': False,\n  'safe_hist': True,\n  'samples': 20,\n  'target_quantum': [\n    # Choi basis for the channel: input qubit at A maps to B when outcome=0 and to C when outcome=1\n    # Represented as the 4 nonzero 4-qubit amplitudes of the classical-quantum Choi state\n    '0000','0110','1001','1111'\n  ],\n  'single_emitters': [0],         # node 0 = data source A\n  'amplitudes': [],\n  'tries_per_edge': 5,\n  'removed_connections': [\n    [1,3],  # forbid S_HB\u2019s hub output (mode 1) \u2192 detector D_C (mode 3)\n    [2,2]   # forbid S_HC\u2019s hub output (mode 2) \u2192 detector D_B (mode 2)\n  ],\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNode indexing (example for Expert):\n 0 = data photon at A  \n 1 = hub mode from S_HB  \n 2 = hub mode from S_HC  \n 3 = heralding detector D_B  \n 4 = heralding detector D_C  \n 5 = B\u2019s output detector (teleported qubit)  \n 6 = C\u2019s output detector  \n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Extend to N outputs (A\u2192{B\u2081,\u2026,B_N}) with an N-port interferometer and N Bell pairs.  \n \u2022 Add a path-encoded quantum or classical control to bias routing.  \n \u2022 Study success probability vs. N under chiral coupling constraints.\n\nThis experiment leverages chiral (one-way) connectivity, passive linear optics, and post-selected entanglement swapping to realize a genuine routing supermap\u2014an entirely new quantum-network primitive for quantum photonics.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme duplicates an existing dual\u2010destination teleportation router by post\u2010selection. To reach PRL\u2010level novelty you must go beyond a simple graph\u2010constraint tweak\u2014e.g. introduce a genuinely new entangling measurement, a higher\u2010dimensional routing supermap, or a novel coherence/causal\u2010order effect.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three truly new Pytheus\u2010compatible network transformations combining \u201cchiral light\u2013matter interaction\u201d and \u201cquantum photonics,\u201d avoiding mere state generation:\n    a) A chiral indefinite\u2010order SWAP\u2010chain (already covered by quantum SWITCH examples).\n    b) A chiral teleportation\u2010router superposition of two teleportation routes (two\u2010branch switch, too close to prior work).\n    c) A chiral coherent superposition of an identity channel (direct photonic transmission) and an entanglement\u2010swapping teleportation channel\u2014i.e. a \u201csuperposition of two network modules\u201d (identity vs. teleport) controlled in a single static interferometer.\n  Step 2: Evaluate novelty/feasibility:\n    \u2022 Novelty: (c) goes beyond teleportation chains and SWITCH gates by superposing two distinct network primitives (do nothing vs. teleport) rather than two orders of the same primitive.\n    \u2022 Feasibility: Pytheus can handle single\u2010photon emitters, Bell\u2010pair sources, linear optics, number\u2010resolving detectors, and \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to enforce chirality (no backward or cross links). No cavities or feedback.\n  Step 3: Choose (c).\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it realizes a new quantum supermap: the coherent superposition of two different quantum\u2010network modules\u2014a direct identity channel and an entanglement\u2010swapping teleportation channel\u2014within one post\u2010selected linear\u2010optical circuit. \n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus\u2019s framework and meets all constraints: it uses abstract Bell pairs and single photons, linear optics, photodetection, and removed_connections to enforce unidirectional (chiral) couplings (direct arm A\u2192D, swap arm A\u2192B\u2192D). No state\u2010generation target, no hybrid entanglement, no feedback control.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is a proposal for Pytheus to design a \u201cchiral coherent superposition of identity and teleportation channels.\u201d  It implements the supermap  \n\u2003\u2003|0\u27e9_ctrl\u27e80|\u2297\ud835\udfd9_{A\u2192D}\u2002+\u2002|1\u27e9_ctrl\u27e81|\u2297Teleport_{A\u2192B\u2192D}  \nin a fully passive, linear\u2010optical, post\u2010selected setup with strictly one\u2010way (chiral) couplings.\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to send an unknown qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 from node A to node D.  Instead of choosing statically \u201cdirect\u201d (identity channel) or \u201cteleport\u201d (via B), we coherently superpose those two network modules under a path\u2010encoded control qubit at A.  The resulting channel is a genuine quantum supermap: a coherent superposition of two distinct quantum\u2010network operations.\n\nProtocol Sketch:\n1. Prepare control qubit \u22230\u27e9+\u22231\u27e9 in the path\u2010degree at A.  A three\u2010mode beamsplitter splits the data photon \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 into two arms conditioned on the control state.\n2. Arm 0 (direct): the data photon travels straight via a single\u2010photon emitter link from A to D.\n3. Arm 1 (teleport): a probabilistic Bell\u2010pair source on link A\u2013B emits one photon to A_swap, one to B_swap.  At node B a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement between A_swap and the data photon implements entanglement swapping, teleporting \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 onto the B\u2010link photon, which travels chiral\u2010ly to D.\n4. The two arms recombine at D on a second beamsplitter.  Post\u2010select on the two heralding detectors at B (the Bell\u2010measurement ancillas) clicking exactly once\u2014this heralds successful teleport in arm 1 and successful identity in arm 0.\n5. The photon emerges at D in the state  \n\u2003\u2003|0\u27e9_ctrl|\u03c8\u27e9_D + |1\u27e9_ctrl|\u03c8\u27e9_D  \ndemonstrating coherent superposition of the identity and teleportation network modules.\n\nChirality Enforcement:\nWe forbid any Bell\u2010pair source or direct link to send photons backward or cross\u2010couple (e.g. Bell source A\u2013B cannot feed D\u2019s detectors except via the teleport arm).  These forbidden edges are encoded with removed_connections.\n\nVisualization:\n   A_data + A_ctrl \u2500\u2500\u2500 BS_in \u2500\u2500\u252c\u2500\u2500 direct arm \u2500\u2500\u25ba D  \n                               \u2502  \n                             teleport arm  \n                               \u2502  \n           BellSource_AB \u2500\u2500\u2500\u25ba  B (Bell meas.) \u2500\u2500\u2500\u25ba D  \n                               \u2502  \n                     Herald ancilla detectors  \n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{'description': 'Chiral superposition of identity vs. teleportation A\u2192D',\n 'foldername': 'chiral_id_vs_teleport',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',              # overlap with ideal supermap Choi state\n 'num_anc': 2,                   # two ancilla detectors at B\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 20,\n 'target_quantum': [\n   # Choi\u2010vector of the controlled\u2010superposition channel (ctrl,data_in \u2192 ctrl,data_out),\n   # nonzero terms correspond to basis |c_in,data_in; c_out,data_out>\n   '0000','0110','1001','1111'\n ],\n 'single_emitters': [0],         # node 0 = data+ctrl source at A\n 'amplitudes': [],\n 'tries_per_edge': 5,\n 'removed_connections': [\n   # forbid backward/cross links:\n   [1,3]  # Bell source port (1) cannot feed direct detector port (3)\n ],\n 'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNode Indexing Guide:\n 0 = combined data\u2010&\u2010control emitter at A  \n 1 = hub output of BellSource_AB feeding Bell meas.  \n 2 = direct arm to D  \n 3 = detector at D  \n Ancilla detectors at B are the two unused ports of the Bell\u2010measurement beam splitters.\n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Extend to superpositions of N different network modules (e.g. direct vs. multi\u2010hop vs. cyclic swap).  \n \u2022 Study coherence as a resource for quantum\u2010network programmability, phase sensitivity, and loss tolerance.  \n\nThis proposal defines a brand\u2010new quantum\u2010network supermap (a coherent superposition of two distinct channels) under chiral\u2010enforced couplings, entirely within Pytheus\u2019s linear\u2010optical, post\u2010selected paradigm. It opens a family of experiments on programmable photonic networks for a Phys.\u2009Rev.\u2009Lett. level contribution."
