    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable Integrated Three-Photon GHZ-Basis Analyzer on Pytheus\n\nAbstract: We implement the target Pytheus-configurable three-photon GHZ-basis analyzer by injecting three unknown photonic qubits and an ancilla Bell pair into a fixed mesh of 50:50 beam splitters augmented with three on-chip electro-optic phase shifters and heralding detectors, thereby unambiguously mapping any incoming triple onto one of the four GHZ basis states. By reprogramming only the EOM voltages\u2014while leaving the linear-optical network unchanged\u2014the same device can project onto the W basis or any rotated three-qubit entangled basis, opening new avenues for adaptive entanglement swapping, secret sharing, and fundamental tests of nonlocality.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement Swapping of 2\u00d72 Toric-Code Logical Qubits via Linear Optics\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate entanglement swapping between two distant logical qubits, each encoded in a minimal 2\u00d72 toric-code patch of four photons at nodes A and D, by performing a post-selected logical Bell measurement on intermediate patches B and C using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, passive linear optics, and ancilla detection. The successful eight-fold coincidence projects detectors 0\u20133 and 12\u201315 onto the unnormalized target quantum state  \n[\"00000000\", \"00001111\", \"11110000\", \"11111111\", \"00110011\", \"00111100\", \"11000011\", \"11001100\"],  \nheralding a fault-tolerant logical Bell pair between A and D without any feed-forward correction.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. This yields a high-fidelity Bell pair between Alice and Bob (the explicit target) within PytHeus\u2019s static linear-optical framework, using two SPDC sources and ancilla detectors without any dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photon-Blockade-Assisted Entanglement Purification of Noisy Bell Pairs\n\nAbstract: We introduce a static linear-optical protocol that combines two probabilistic noisy Bell-pair sources with single-emitter photon-blockade nodes to suppress double-pair emissions and distill the target high-fidelity Bell state |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9=(|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9)/\u221a2. By performing a parity check on one photon from each pair via a 50:50 beam splitter and enforcing \u22641-photon inputs through photon-blockade ancillae, specific heralding detection patterns project the remaining photons onto the purified Bell state within the PyTheus framework.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation of a Single-Photon Qubit through a Coherent Superposition of Markovian and Non-Markovian Channels\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and analyze an optical teleportation experiment in which an unknown target qubit is split into two rails that interact with engineered ancilla chains\u2014one Markovian and one non-Markovian\u2014before being coherently recombined. A Bell-state measurement at Charlie, conditioned on specific click patterns, heralds the successful teleportation of the target quantum to Bob, with fidelity controlled by beam-splitter reflectivities and memory-chain parameters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively. This proof-of-principle experiment doubles qubit throughput in one step without dynamic feed-forward or cavity interfaces, using on-demand SiV\u2013photon entanglement and a bespoke four\u2010click Bell analyzer to herald cross-teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Cyclic Indefinite\u2010Order Entanglement\u2010Swapping Switch for the Three-State Bargmann Invariant\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a static linear-optical network that path-controls a single photon to cyclically superpose three successive Bell\u2013swap orders among unknown qubits A, B, and C, recombining all nine modes in a fixed nine-port interferometer and reading out a binary \u201c+\u201d/\u201c\u2013\u201d outcome. The target is the real part of the three-state Bargmann invariant Re\u2009Tr(\u03c1_A\u2009\u03c1_B\u2009\u03c1_C), whose quantized response statistics directly realize a genuine three-point quantum metric beyond pairwise SWAP tests.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Temporal-Mode Multiplexed Entanglement Swapping with Single Ancilla\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate a static linear-optical station that uses one ancilla Bell pair and a single delay loop to perform two sequential entanglement swaps on unknown qubit pairs arriving in time bins t\u2081 and t\u2082, halving the ancillary resource requirement. The experiment explicitly targets eight two-click detection patterns (four at t\u2081, four at t\u2082) on number-resolving, time-tagging detectors, each pattern heralding a successful swap and showcasing a resonator-inspired temporal coupling strategy for resource-efficient quantum network primitives.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Ancilla-Controlled Programmable Coherent Bell Analyzer\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and simulate a fully coherent measurement supermap\u2014targeting programmable photonic quantum processors\u2014that employs a single Purcell-enhanced on-demand emitter as ancilla (mode 2) to coherently choose between Z- and X-basis Bell measurements on two SPDC-generated photons (modes 0 & 1) within a static linear-optical network. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Post-Selected Linear-Optics Teleportation of Wigner-Negative Qutrits in d = 3\n\nAbstract: We design a discrete-variable teleportation channel in dimension d = 3 using a pre-shared probabilistic qutrit Bell pair, four single-photon ancillas, and number-resolving detectors within a linear-optics interferometer to probabilistically teleport any unknown qutrit input. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Mode\u2010Division\u2010Multiplexed On\u2010Chip Purification of 3-Dimensional Bell Pairs\n\nAbstract: We propose an integrated\u2010optics node that purifies two probabilistic qutrit photon\u2010pair sources into the target high\u2010fidelity 3-dimensional Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9+|22\u27e9 by routing Alice\u2019s spatial modes and Bob\u2019s mode\u2010division\u2010multiplexed channels through a 6\u00d76 linear\u2010optic parity\u2010check circuit with two ancilla heralding detectors. Rotated-basis joint measurements at repeater nodes X and Y (modes 1 & 2) jointly set the phase \u03c6, yielding deterministic teleportation and a \u03c6-dependent two-photon click pattern at herald detectors [0, 3] that confirms the controlled-phase signature.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nHeralded Linear\u2010Optical 1\u21922 QuTrIt Telecloning via Resonance-Dip Multiport Bell Measurement\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe propose and analyze a fully linear-optical implementation of the first 1\u21922 qutrit telecloner, in which three probabilistic qutrit-entangled photon-pair sources feed a balanced three-mode multiport Bell measurement module synchronized by identical delay-loop \u201cresonators.\u201d Success of the telecloning is unambiguously heralded by a generalized Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel resonance dip in triple-coincidence ancilla detections, conditionally projecting the two receivers into the optimal symmetric clones of the unknown input qutrit.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d\n\nAbstract: We realize the target two-node quantum router transformation \n|c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297(swap_if_c=1\u2009|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083) \nby implementing a heralded 4\u00d74 controlled-SWAP in a compact linear-optical circuit, in which a single control qubit encoded in two spectral modes at Alice coherently routes an arbitrary spatially encoded data qubit to remote nodes Charlie (modes 4,5) or David (modes 6,7) with number-resolving ancilla detection. Chiral (unidirectional) coupling is enforced by forbidding any Bell\u2010pair source from connecting \u201cupstream\u201d to \u201cdownstream\u201d backwards (i.e. once a photon leaves A toward B it cannot return), mimicking spin\u2010momentum\u2010locking waveguides in an abstract way. This network can be generalized to N hops, illustrating how chiral couplers reduce resource overhead for long\u2010distance teleportation.\n\nVisualization:\n  - Single\u2010photon source at A emits the data qubit into the network.  \n  - Three Bell\u2010pair sources create pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D (each pair source probabilistic).  \n  - At node B: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the incoming data photon from A and one photon of the AB pair \u2192 swaps entanglement to B\u2013C link.  \n  - At node C: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the swapped photon from B\u2013C and one photon of the C\u2013D pair \u2192 final entanglement between A data and D.  \n  - After post\u2010selection, the output qubit emerges at D with the state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9, completing a two\u2010dimensional teleportation channel \u22230\u27e9\u2192\u22230\u27e9, \u22231\u27e9\u2192\u22231\u27e9.\n  - No direct source\u2010detector connections backward along the chain, enforced by removed_connections to encode chirality.\n\nConfig Template for Pytheus:\n{'description': 'Chiral 3\u2010hop teleportation chain A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D',\n 'foldername': 'chiral_3hop_teleport',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,    # loosened threshold for post\u2010selection\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',   # count\u2010rate overlap with ideal teleportation channel\n 'num_anc': 4,        # ancilla detectors for two Bell measurements (2 each)\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 20,\n 'target_quantum': ['00','11'],  # ideal identity channel on logical qubit A\u2192D\n 'single_emitters': [0],         # node 0 = A data photon\n 'amplitudes': [],\n 'tries_per_edge': 5,\n 'removed_connections': [\n     # forbid direct A\u2192C, A\u2192D, B\u2192D sources\n     [0,2],[0,3],[1,3]\n ],\n 'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNodes indexing:\n 0 = data photon source at A  \n 1,2,3 = detectors at B (post\u2010Bell measurement), C (post\u2010Bell measurement), D (output)  \n Ancillary detectors correspond to the other two outputs of each Bell\u2010measurement beam\u2010splitter.\n\nThis design can be extended to N hops simply by adding more Bell\u2010pair sources, more \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to enforce one\u2010way propagation, and extra measurement nodes. It realizes the quantum network channel that permutes three unknown qubit inputs (at A, B, C) in a cycle\u2014A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A\u2014using only Bell\u2010pair sources, linear optics, and photon detection:\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to implement the channel  \n  \u2223\u03c8_A\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03d5_B\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03c7_C\u27e9  \u21a6  \u2223\u03c7_D\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03c8_E\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03d5_F\u27e9  \nwhere detectors D, E, F sit at nodes A, B, C respectively, and the mapping is the cyclic permutation (A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A).  \n 1. Place three probabilistic Bell-pair sources on links AB, BC, and CA in a ring.  \n 2. At node B, perform a post-selected Bell measurement between the incoming qubit from A and one photon from the AB pair \u2192 swaps A\u2019s state onto the BC link.  \n 3. At node C, perform a Bell measurement between that swapped photon and one from the BC pair \u2192 swaps A\u2019s state onto the CA link.  \n 4. At node A, perform a Bell measurement between that swapped photon and one from the CA pair \u2192 finalizes C\u2192A teleportation.  \n 5. Simultaneously perform the analogous chain of three measurements starting from B\u2192C\u2192A\u2192B and C\u2192A\u2192B\u2192C\u2014i.e. three interlaced teleportation chains\u2014so that after post-selection each node\u2019s input ends up at the next node clockwise.  \n 6. Enforce chirality (unidirectional coupling) by forbidding any Bell source from connecting \u201cagainst\u201d the ring direction using removed_connections.\n\nVisualization of abstract layout:\n  Sources:  \n    S_AB emits to detectors at A' and B'.  \n    S_BC emits to B\u2033 and C'.  \n    S_CA emits to C\u2033 and A\u2033.  \n  Measurements:  \n    M_B on (A', B'), M_C on (B\u2033, C'), M_A on (C\u2033, A\u2033)  \n  Post-selected detections at A (detector D), B (E), C (F) yield the permuted outputs.\n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{'description': 'Chiral cyclic teleportation ring A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192A',\n 'foldername': 'cyclic_chiral_teleport',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',             # It teleports an unknown qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 from node A to node D via two distinct chiral entanglement\u2010swapping routes\u2014A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D and A\u2192C\u2192B\u2192D\u2014coherently superposed by an initial and final beam splitter.\n\nExplanation:\n1. A single\u2010photon source at A emits the data qubit and feeds it into a 50:50 beam splitter \u2192 two spatial arms (paths 0 and 1).  \n2. Path 0 implements entanglement swapping along the chiral chain A\u2192B (Bell pair on AB) then B\u2192C (Bell pair on BC).  \n   Path 1 implements entanglement swapping along A\u2192C (Bell pair on AC) then C\u2192B (Bell pair on CB).  \n3. After the two swap stages in each arm, the two resulting photons recombine on a second 50:50 beam splitter.  \n4. Post\u2010selecting on successful detections at B and C in each arm and the final detector at D yields a teleportation channel A\u2192D.  \n5. Because the data qubit traveled through both network topologies in superposition, the output exhibits interference fringes as a function of relative phase\u2014demonstrating \u201csuperposed network topologies\u201d in a chiral photonic setting.\n\nVisualization of logical layout (top view):\n  [A data source]  \n       \u2502  \n      BS_in  \n     \u2571    \u2572  \n  arm0    arm1  \n   \u2502       \u2502  \n  Swap0_1  Swap1_1   \u2190 Bell meas. stage 1 on AB\u2013BC vs. AC\u2013CB  \n   \u2502       \u2502  \n  Swap0_2  Swap1_2   \u2190 Bell meas. stage 2  \n     \u2572    \u2571  \n      BS_out  \n       \u2502  \n      [D detector]\n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{\n  'description': 'Superposition of two chiral teleportation routes A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D vs. A\u2192C\u2192B\u2192D',\n  'foldername': 'chiral_route_superposition',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'ftol': 1e-6,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',            # overlap with ideal identity channel A\u2192D\n  'num_anc': 4,                 # two ancilla detections per swap stage\n  'num_pre': 1,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'imaginary': False,\n  'safe_hist': True,\n  'samples': 20,\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],# identity (teleportation) channel\u2019s Choi basis\n  'single_emitters': [0],       # node 0 = data source at A\n  'amplitudes': [],\n  'tries_per_edge': 5,\n  'removed_connections': [\n    # enforce chiral, arm\u2010separated links and forbid backward/cross couplings\n    [0,4], [0,5],  # data source (0) cannot feed wrong Bell\u2010meas. ports\n    [1,6], [1,7]   # Bell\u2010pair source on AB/BC cannot feed AC/CB ports\n  ],\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNode indexing guide (to be adapted by the Expert):\n 0 = data\u2010photon emitter (A)  \n 1\u20134 = four Bell\u2010pair sources:  \n     S_AB (emits to 2,3), S_BC (3,4) in arm 0; Swap\u2010C arm: A\u2192C\u2192D (Bell pair on AC, Bell\u2010swap measurement at C, then photon to D)  \n\nAn initial three-port beam splitter symmetrically splits the data photon into arms 0,1,2.  \nArms 1 and 2 each meet one half of a Bell pair (from sources S_AB, S_AC) and undergo a post-selected Bell measurement (2 ancilla detectors each).  \nAll three arms recombine on a three-port interferometer.  \nConditioned on herald clicks in the two swap\u2010arm measurements, the photon emerges at D in the coherent superposition of the three network routes, exhibiting interference fringes as we vary internal phases.\n\nVisualization (abstract):\n      [A data source]\u2500\u2500\u2500\u252c\u2500\u2500BS_in\u2500\u2500\u2500\u252c\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u252c\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510  \n                       \u2502          \u2502     \u2502     \u2502  \n                     arm0       arm1  arm2  (unused ancilla)  \n                       \u2502          \u2502     \u2502  \n                     (direct)  Bell-swap@B  Bell-swap@C  \n                       \u2502          \u2502     \u2502  \n                     \u2500\u2500\u2534\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2534\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2534\u2500  \n                             BS_out  \n                               \u2502  \n                             [D detector]\n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{\n 'description': 'Chiral 3-path teleportation superposition A\u2192D',\n 'foldername': 'chiral_3path_superposition',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',                   # Prepare control qubit \u22230\u27e9+\u22231\u27e9 in the path\u2010degree at A.  A three\u2010mode beamsplitter splits the data photon \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 into two arms conditioned on the control state.\n2. Arm 0 (direct): the data photon travels straight via a single\u2010photon emitter link from A to D.\n3. Arm 1 (teleport): a probabilistic Bell\u2010pair source on link A\u2013B emits one photon to A_swap, one to B_swap. The two arms recombine at D on a second beamsplitter.  Post\u2010select on the two heralding detectors at B (the Bell\u2010measurement ancillas) clicking exactly once\u2014this heralds successful teleport in arm 1 and successful identity in arm 0.\n5. The photon emerges at D in the state  \n\u2003\u2003|0\u27e9_ctrl|\u03c8\u27e9_D + |1\u27e9_ctrl|\u03c8\u27e9_D  \ndemonstrating coherent superposition of the identity and teleportation network modules.\n\nChirality Enforcement:\nWe forbid any Bell\u2010pair source or direct link to send photons backward or cross\u2010couple (e.g. Bell source A\u2013B cannot feed D\u2019s detectors except via the teleport arm).     "output": "Thought: This proposal merely restates the \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\u201d primitive already in the ensemble list, differing only by enforcing one-way (chiral) links via removed_connections.     "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Scalable Scheduling Policies for Quantum Satellite Networks\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Constraints on Gaussian Error Channels and Measurements for Quantum\n  Communication\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Quantum transport efficiency in noisy random-removal and small-world\n  networks\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. THE FEEDBACK IS INCREDIBLE IMPORTANT !!! FOR SURE LOOK AT THEM AND UNDERSTAND THE CORE IDEA OF THEM!! A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. Chiral (unidirectional) coupling is enforced by forbidding any Bell\u2010pair source from connecting \u201cupstream\u201d to \u201cdownstream\u201d backwards (i.e. once a photon leaves A toward B it cannot return), mimicking spin\u2010momentum\u2010locking waveguides in an abstract way. This network can be generalized to N hops, illustrating how chiral couplers reduce resource overhead for long\u2010distance teleportation.\n\nVisualization:\n  - Single\u2010photon source at A emits the data qubit into the network.  \n  - Three Bell\u2010pair sources create pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D (each pair source probabilistic).  \n  - At node B: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the incoming data photon from A and one photon of the AB pair \u2192 swaps entanglement to B\u2013C link.  \n  - At node C: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the swapped photon from B\u2013C and one photon of the C\u2013D pair \u2192 final entanglement between A data and D.  \n  - After post\u2010selection, the output qubit emerges at D with the state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9, completing a two\u2010dimensional teleportation channel \u22230\u27e9\u2192\u22230\u27e9, \u22231\u27e9\u2192\u22231\u27e9.\n  - No cavities, feedback control, or hybrid entanglement are needed.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a proposal for Pytheus to design a \u201cchiral cyclic teleportation ring\u201d across three nodes A, B, C. It realizes the quantum network channel that permutes three unknown qubit inputs (at A, B, C) in a cycle\u2014A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A\u2014using only Bell\u2010pair sources, linear optics, and photon detection:\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to implement the channel  \n  \u2223\u03c8_A\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03d5_B\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03c7_C\u27e9  \u21a6  \u2223\u03c7_D\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03c8_E\u27e9\u2297\u2223\u03d5_F\u27e9  \nwhere detectors D, E, F sit at nodes A, B, C respectively, and the mapping is the cyclic permutation (A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A).  \n 1. Place three probabilistic Bell-pair sources on links AB, BC, and CA in a ring.  \n 2. At node B, perform a post-selected Bell measurement between the incoming qubit from A and one photon from the AB pair \u2192 swaps A\u2019s state onto the BC link.  \n 3. At node C, perform a Bell measurement between that swapped photon and one from the BC pair \u2192 swaps A\u2019s state onto the CA link.  \n 4. At node A, perform a Bell measurement between that swapped photon and one from the CA pair \u2192 finalizes C\u2192A teleportation.  \n 5. Simultaneously perform the analogous chain of three measurements starting from B\u2192C\u2192A\u2192B and C\u2192A\u2192B\u2192C\u2014i.e. three interlaced teleportation chains\u2014so that after post-selection each node\u2019s input ends up at the next node clockwise.  \n 6. Enforce chirality (unidirectional coupling) by forbidding any Bell source from connecting \u201cagainst\u201d the ring direction using removed_connections.\n\nVisualization of abstract layout:\n  Sources:  \n    S_AB emits to detectors at A' and B'.  \n    S_BC emits to B\u2033 and C'.  \n    S_CA emits to C\u2033 and A\u2033.  \n  Measurements:  \n    M_B on (A', B'), M_C on (B\u2033, C'), M_A on (C\u2033, A\u2033)  \n  Post-selected detections at A (detector D), B (E), C (F) yield the permuted outputs.\n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{'description': 'Chiral cyclic teleportation ring A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192A',\n 'foldername': 'cyclic_chiral_teleport',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',             # overlap with ideal permutation channel\n 'num_anc': 3,                 # one ancilla detector per Bell measurement\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 20,\n 'target_quantum': [\n   # At hub H, a three-mode linear-optical interferometer combines A_data, H_B, and H_C. No state\u2010generation target, no hybrid entanglement, no feedback control.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is a proposal for Pytheus to design a \u201cchiral coherent superposition of identity and teleportation channels.\u201d  It implements the supermap  \n\u2003\u2003|0\u27e9_ctrl\u27e80|\u2297\ud835\udfd9_{A\u2192D}\u2002+\u2002|1\u27e9_ctrl\u27e81|\u2297Teleport_{A\u2192B\u2192D}  \nin a fully passive, linear\u2010optical, post\u2010selected setup with strictly one\u2010way (chiral) couplings.\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to send an unknown qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 from node A to node D.  Instead of choosing statically \u201cdirect\u201d (identity channel) or \u201cteleport\u201d (via B), we coherently superpose those two network modules under a path\u2010encoded control qubit at A.  The resulting channel is a genuine quantum supermap: a coherent superposition of two distinct quantum\u2010network operations.\n\nProtocol Sketch:\n1. Prepare control qubit \u22230\u27e9+\u22231\u27e9 in the path\u2010degree at A.  A three\u2010mode beamsplitter splits the data photon \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 into two arms conditioned on the control state.\n2. Arm 0 (direct): the data photon travels straight via a single\u2010photon emitter link from A to D.\n3. Arm 1 (teleport): a probabilistic Bell\u2010pair source on link A\u2013B emits one photon to A_swap, one to B_swap.  At node B a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement between A_swap and the data photon implements entanglement swapping, teleporting \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 onto the B\u2010link photon, which travels chiral\u2010ly to D.\n4. The two arms recombine at D on a second beamsplitter.  Post\u2010select on the two heralding detectors at B (the Bell\u2010measurement ancillas) clicking exactly once\u2014this heralds successful teleport in arm 1 and successful identity in arm 0.\n5. The photon emerges at D in the state  \n\u2003\u2003|0\u27e9_ctrl|\u03c8\u27e9_D + |1\u27e9_ctrl|\u03c8\u27e9_D  \ndemonstrating coherent superposition of the identity and teleportation network modules.\n\nChirality Enforcement:\nWe forbid any Bell\u2010pair source or direct link to send photons backward or cross\u2010couple (e.g. Bell source A\u2013B cannot feed D\u2019s detectors except via the teleport arm).  These forbidden edges are encoded with removed_connections.\n\nVisualization:\n   A_data + A_ctrl \u2500\u2500\u2500 BS_in \u2500\u2500\u252c\u2500\u2500 direct arm \u2500\u2500\u25ba D  \n                               \u2502  \n                             teleport arm  \n                               \u2502  \n           BellSource_AB \u2500\u2500\u2500\u25ba  B (Bell meas.) \u2500\u2500\u2500\u25ba D  \n                               \u2502  \n                     Herald ancilla detectors  \n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{'description': 'Chiral superposition of identity vs. teleportation A\u2192D',\n 'foldername': 'chiral_id_vs_teleport',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',              # overlap with ideal supermap Choi state\n 'num_anc': 2,                   # two ancilla detectors at B\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 20,\n 'target_quantum': [\n   # Choi\u2010vector of the controlled\u2010superposition channel (ctrl,data_in \u2192 ctrl,data_out),\n   # nonzero terms correspond to basis |c_in,data_in;     "output": "Here is a proposal for Pytheus to design a \u201cchiral quantum multiplexer\u2013demultiplexer\u201d channel.  It implements the identity on two qubits (A,B\u2192E,F) but forces the information to flow through a single\u2010mode chiral \u201ctrunk\u201d H.  In other words, the two input qubits at A and B are fused at a central hub H into one photonic mode, sent onward, and then split back into two qubits at E and F\u2014solely via passive, post\u2010selected linear optics and Bell\u2010pair sources, with unidirectional (chiral) couplings enforced by removed_connections.\n\nExplanation:\n\u2022 Goal channel \u039b:  \n   \u03c1_{AB}  \u2192  \u03c1_{EF}  with  \u03c1_{EF}=\u03c1_{AB}  (identity on two qubits).  \n  But no direct A\u2192E or B\u2192F link is allowed; all photons must pass through hub H.\n\nScheme:\n1. Bell\u2010pair source S\u2081 on link A\u2013H\u2081 emits one half to A_mux and one to H_mux1.  \n2. Bell\u2010pair source S\u2082 on link B\u2013H\u2082 emits one half to B_mux and one to H_mux2.  \n3. At hub H perform a four\u2010photon \u201cmultiplexer\u201d measurement (mixing H_mux1, H_mux2, and the two data photons A_mux, B_mux on a small LO network); two ancilla detectors herald the fusion of the two qubits into a single photonic mode H_out.  \n4. Send that single photon unidirectionally from H_out to a second hub H\u2032 without any backward or cross\u2010coupling (enforced via removed_connections).  \n5. At H\u2032, prepare two new Bell pairs S\u2083 (H\u2032\u2013E) and S\u2084 (H\u2032\u2013F).  Perform a four\u2010photon \u201cdemultiplexer\u201d measurement mixing H_out and the two halves H\u2032_E, H\u2032_F on a second LO block; two ancilla detectors herald the fission back into two qubits on modes E and F.  \n6. Upon all four herald-clicks, the two remaining photons at E and F carry exactly the original state of (A,B).  This realizes a chiral two\u2010qubit identity channel via a 1-mode trunk.\n\nVisualization (logical):\n      A\u2500\u2500\u252c                          \u2500\u2500\u25baE  \n          \u2502                          \u2502  \n      B\u2500\u2500\u252c\u2534\u2500\u2500Mux @H\u2500\u2500H_out\u2500\u2500Demux @H\u2032\u2534\u2500\u2500\u25baF  \n         Bell\u2081  Bell\u2082              Bell\u2083  Bell\u2084  \n         ancilla ancilla           ancilla ancilla  \n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{\n  'description': 'Chiral 2\u21921\u21922 quantum multiplexer\u2013demultiplexer',\n  'foldername': 'chiral_mux_demux',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n  'edges_tried': 30,\n  'ftol': 1e-6,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',  \n  'num_anc': 4,                       # only Bell\u2010pair sources\n  'amplitudes': [],\n  'tries_per_edge': 5,\n  'removed_connections': [\n    # forbid any direct A\u2192E (mode 0\u21922) or B\u2192F (1\u21923)\n    [0,2],[1,3],\n    # forbid any back\u2010coupling at trunk: no H_out\u2192mux detectors\n    [4,0],[5,1]\n  ],\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNode indexing (example):\n 0,1 = data photons after mux\u2010pair sources S\u2081,S\u2082  \n 2,3 = final output detectors at E,F  \n 4,5 = heralding detectors for the mux @H  \n 6,7 = heralding detectors for the demux @H\u2032  \n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Extend to an N\u21921\u2192N photonic fan-in/fan-out network by adding more Bell pairs and larger LO\u2010measurements.  \n \u2022 Study resource scaling (Bell pairs and ancillas) vs. success probability under chiral constraints.  \n \u2022 Explore fault tolerance of multiplexed quantum channels in chiral photonic architectures.\n\nThis target defines a new network-level CPTP map\u2014passive, chiral quantum multiplexing and demultiplexing\u2014purely by linear optics, Bell\u2010pair sources, and post\u2010selection. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. After the two swap stages in each arm, the two resulting photons recombine on a second 50:50 beam splitter.  \n4. Post\u2010selecting on successful detections at B and C in each arm and the final detector at D yields a teleportation channel A\u2192D.  \n5. Because the data qubit traveled through both network topologies in superposition, the output exhibits interference fringes as a function of relative phase\u2014demonstrating \u201csuperposed network topologies\u201d in a chiral photonic setting.\n\nVisualization of logical layout (top view):\n  [A data source]  \n       \u2502  \n      BS_in  \n     \u2571    \u2572  \n  arm0    arm1  \n   \u2502       \u2502  \n  Swap0_1  Swap1_1   \u2190 Bell meas. stage 1 on AB\u2013BC vs. AC\u2013CB  \n   \u2502       \u2502  \n  Swap0_2  Swap1_2   \u2190 Bell meas. stage 2  \n     \u2572    \u2571  \n      BS_out  \n       \u2502  \n      [D detector]\n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{\n  'description': 'Superposition of two chiral teleportation routes A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D vs. A\u2192C\u2192B\u2192D',\n  'foldername': 'chiral_route_superposition',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'ftol': 1e-6,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',            # overlap with ideal identity channel A\u2192D\n  'num_anc': 4,                 # two ancilla detections per swap stage\n  'num_pre': 1,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'imaginary': False,\n  'safe_hist': True,\n  'samples': 20,\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],# identity (teleportation) channel\u2019s Choi basis\n  'single_emitters': [0],       # node 0 = data source at A\n  'amplitudes': [],\n  'tries_per_edge': 5,\n  'removed_connections': [\n    # enforce chiral, arm\u2010separated links and forbid backward/cross couplings\n    [0,4], [0,5],  # data source (0) cannot feed wrong Bell\u2010meas. ports\n    [1,6], [1,7]   # Bell\u2010pair source on AB/BC cannot feed AC/CB ports\n  ],\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNode indexing guide (to be adapted by the Expert):\n 0 = data\u2010photon emitter (A)  \n 1\u20134 = four Bell\u2010pair sources:  \n     S_AB (emits to 2,3), S_BC (3,4) in arm 0; All photon links are enforced one-way (\u201cchiral\u201d) by removed_connections.\n\nLogical layout:\n  A: emits data \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 and control qutrit (3-mode splitter)  \n   \u2514\u2192 path i \u2192 Bell-swap at node \u03c0(i,1), then \u03c0(i,2), then \u03c0(i,3)  \n  Links: Bell sources on AB, BC, CD  \n  Measurements: at B, C, D perform post-selected Bell measurements  \n  E: recombine control arms \u2192 output \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 at E and control readout  \n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{\n 'description': 'Chiral 3-switch entanglement-swapping supermap A\u2192E',\n 'foldername': 'chiral_3switch_swap',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 50,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',               # overlap with ideal 3-switch Choi process\n 'num_anc': 6,                    # two ancilla detectors per Bell measurement\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 30,\n 'target_quantum': [\n   # 9-mode Choi basis: control_qutrit(3) \u00d7 data_in(2) \u2192 control_qutrit(3) \u00d7 data_out(2)\n   # Flattened into 3+1+3+1=8 photons across 9 modes; Two ancilla number-resolving detectors at E herald successful operation on exactly one click each from the Bell-pair halves.  \n5.     "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable Integrated Three-Photon GHZ-Basis Analyzer on Pytheus\n\nAbstract: We implement the target Pytheus-configurable three-photon GHZ-basis analyzer by injecting three unknown photonic qubits and an ancilla Bell pair into a fixed mesh of 50:50 beam splitters augmented with three on-chip electro-optic phase shifters and heralding detectors, thereby unambiguously mapping any incoming triple onto one of the four GHZ basis states. By reprogramming only the EOM voltages\u2014while leaving the linear-optical network unchanged\u2014the same device can project onto the W basis or any rotated three-qubit entangled basis, opening new avenues for adaptive entanglement swapping, secret sharing, and fundamental tests of nonlocality.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement Swapping of 2\u00d72 Toric-Code Logical Qubits via Linear Optics\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate entanglement swapping between two distant logical qubits, each encoded in a minimal 2\u00d72 toric-code patch of four photons at nodes A and D, by performing a post-selected logical Bell measurement on intermediate patches B and C using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, passive linear optics, and ancilla detection. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a proposal for Pytheus to design a \u201cchiral, multi\u2010hop teleportation chain\u201d that implements directional entanglement swapping (i.e. a chiral quantum repeater) between four nodes A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to teleport an unknown qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 from node A to node D by performing sequential entanglement\u2010swapping steps at intermediate nodes B and C, using only probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, single\u2010photon sources, linear optics, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. Chiral (unidirectional) coupling is enforced by forbidding any Bell\u2010pair source from connecting \u201cupstream\u201d to \u201cdownstream\u201d backwards (i.e. once a photon leaves A toward B it cannot return), mimicking spin\u2010momentum\u2010locking waveguides in an abstract way. This network can be generalized to N hops, illustrating how chiral couplers reduce resource overhead for long\u2010distance teleportation.\n\nVisualization:\n  - Single\u2010photon source at A emits the data qubit into the network.  \n  - Three Bell\u2010pair sources create pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D (each pair source probabilistic).  \n  - At node B: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the incoming data photon from A and one photon of the AB pair \u2192 swaps entanglement to B\u2013C link.  \n  - At node C: perform a post\u2010selected Bell\u2010state measurement on the swapped photon from B\u2013C and one photon of the C\u2013D pair \u2192 final entanglement between A data and D.  \n  - After post\u2010selection, the output qubit emerges at D with the state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9, completing a two\u2010dimensional teleportation channel \u22230\u27e9\u2192\u22230\u27e9, \u22231\u27e9\u2192\u22231\u27e9.\n  - No direct source\u2010detector connections backward along the chain, enforced by removed_connections to encode chirality.\n\nConfig Template for Pytheus:\n{'description': 'Chiral 3\u2010hop teleportation chain A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D',\n 'foldername': 'chiral_3hop_teleport',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,    # loosened threshold for post\u2010selection\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',   # count\u2010rate overlap with ideal teleportation channel\n 'num_anc': 4,        # ancilla detectors for two Bell measurements (2 each)\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 20,\n 'target_quantum': ['00','11'],  # ideal identity channel on logical qubit A\u2192D\n 'single_emitters': [0],         # node 0 = A data photon\n 'amplitudes': [],\n 'tries_per_edge': 5,\n 'removed_connections': [\n     # forbid direct A\u2192C, A\u2192D, B\u2192D sources\n     [0,2],[0,3],[1,3]\n ],\n 'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNodes indexing:\n 0 = data photon source at A  \n 1,2,3 = detectors at B (post\u2010Bell measurement), C (post\u2010Bell measurement), D (output)  \n Ancillary detectors correspond to the other two outputs of each Bell\u2010measurement beam\u2010splitter.\n\nThis design can be extended to N hops simply by adding more Bell\u2010pair sources, more \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to enforce one\u2010way propagation, and extra measurement nodes. The Expert can hand off this abstract target to Pytheus, recover a linear\u2010optics circuit, and write up the first demonstration of a purely chiral, multi\u2010hop entanglement\u2010swapping teleportation network.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This \u201cchiral multi\u2010hop teleportation chain\u201d is just the textbook sequential entanglement\u2010swapping repeater extended with a removed_connections trick to enforce one\u2010way links. It offers no new Bell\u2010measurement primitive or exotic causality superposition beyond standard multi\u2010link swapping (see, e.g., basic two\u2010link entanglement swapping, temporal\u2010mode multiplexing, flux\u2010controlled chiral teleportation routing). For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. After post-selection, the remaining photons at modes 0 and 1 carry the CZ-rotated qubits and exit to detectors at A_out and C_out.  \n6. Chirality: We forbid any source from sending photons \u201cbackwards\u201d (e.g. S_AE cannot feed C_out ports, S_CE cannot feed A_out ports), encoded via removed_connections.\n\nVisualization (abstract):\n   A_in(0)\u2500\u2500\u252c\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510  \n            \u2502    \u2502  \n  S_AE(2\u21943)\u2500\u253c Bell-swap-block @ E \u2500\u253c\u2500\u2500 A_out  \n            \u2502    \u2502  \n   C_in(1)\u2500\u2500\u2534 S_CE(4\u21945)\u2500\u2534\u2500\u2500 C_out  \n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{'description': 'Chiral heralded nonlocal CZ gate A\u2013C via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername': 'chiral_nonlocal_CZ',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n 'edges_tried': 30,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',                #     "output": "Here is a proposal for Pytheus to design a \u201cchiral 1\u21922 universal telecloning of a qutrit\u201d experiment.  It implements the optimal symmetric 1\u21922 telecloning CPTP map for a three-level system (qutrit) in a strictly one-way (chiral) linear-optical network, using only Bell-pair sources, a single qutrit\u2010emitter, passive interferometers and post-selected photon-number-resolving detectors.\n\nExplanation  \nWe want to take an unknown qutrit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and produce two approximate clones at nodes B and C, each with the optimal fidelity 5/9.  This is a genuine network-level CPTP transformation (not mere state generation).  All photon paths go strictly \u201coutward\u201d from A to B/C\u2014no backward or cross coupling\u2014enforced by removed_connections.\n\nProtocol Sketch  \n1) Single-photon qutrit emitter at A encodes \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 across 3 spatial modes.  \n2) Two probabilistic three-dimensional Bell-pair sources:  \n   \u2022 S_AB emits one photon to A_measure port and one to node B\u2019s share.  \n   \u2022 S_AC emits one photon to A_measure port and one to node C\u2019s share.  \n3) At A we perform a single post-selected four-photon joint measurement (a linear-optical generalized Bell measurement for telecloning a qutrit).  Two ancilla detectors herald the successful telecloning outcome.  \n4) Upon herald, the remaining photons at B and C carry two optimal clones of \u2223\u03c8\u27e9.  \n\nChirality  \nWe forbid any source from sending photons back into A or into the \u201cwrong\u201d measurement port at A.  These forbidden edges are encoded via removed_connections.\n\nPytheus Configuration Template  \n{  \n  'description': 'Chiral 1\u21922 universal telecloning of a qutrit',  \n  'foldername': 'chiral_teleclone_3d',  \n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,  \n  'edges_tried': 40,  \n  'ftol': 1e-6,  \n  'loss_func': 'cr',                # maximize overlap with ideal telecloning Choi state  \n  'num_anc': 2,                     # two heralding detectors at A  \n  'num_pre': 1,  \n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',  \n  'imaginary': False,  \n  'safe_hist': True,  \n  'samples': 20,  \n  'dimensions': [3,3],              # qutrit \u2192 (qutrit, qutrit) channel  \n  'target_quantum': [                # the 27 nonzero amplitudes of the telecloning Choi vector  \n    # expert will fill in the 3\u00d73\u00d73\u00d73=81-dimensional Choi vector; here is a schematic placeholder  \n    '0000','0011','0022',\u2026,'2222'  \n  ],  \n  'single_emitters': [0],            # node 0 = qutrit emitter A  \n  'tries_per_edge': 5,  \n  'removed_connections': [           # enforce one-way/chiral: no cross-feeding  \n    [1,5],  # forbid S_AB\u2019s A_measure port (mode 1) \u2192 C_measure port (mode 5)  \n    [2,4]   # forbid S_AC\u2019s A_measure port (mode 2) \u2192 B_measure port (mode 4)  \n  ],  \n  'number_resolving': True  \n}\n\nNode-index guide (example)  \n 0 = qutrit emitter at A  \n 1 = A_measure port for Bell pair S_AB  \n 2 = A_measure port for Bell pair S_AC  \n 3 = first ancilla detector (herald)  \n 4 = second ancilla detector (herald)  \n 5 = B_clone output  \n 6 = C_clone output  \n\nGeneralization  \n\u2022 Extend to 1\u2192N telecloning of qudits by adding N Bell-pair sources and a single N+1-photon joint measurement at A.  \n\u2022 Study how chirality (enforced by removed_connections) affects resource scaling and success probability.  \n\u2022 Investigate hybrid dimensional telecloning (qutrit\u2192qubit+qubit+\u2026), programmable superposition of different 1\u21922 cloning fidelities, etc.\n\nThis experiment realizes a brand-new, chiral channel\u2014the 1\u21922 telecloning supermap for a three-level system\u2014purely in Pytheus\u2019s linear-optical, post-selected framework, and opens a whole family of high-dimensional, one-to-many quantum-network transformations."

At node A perform one joint post-selected four-photon linear-optical measurement (a generalized Bell\u2010swap measurement on the input qubit plus one photon from each Bell pair).  Outcome \u201csuccess\u201d is heralded by two ancilla detectors.  \n3. Conditioned on that herald, the remaining photon halves at B, C, D form the three quantum shares of the secret.  \n4. Enforce chirality by forbidding any Bell source to send photons backward or cross-link (e.g. no A\u2013B source to C or D\u2019s measurement ports), via the removed_connections keyword.\n\nVisualization:\n   [Input qubit at A]\u2500\u2500\u252c\u2500\u2500Bell_AB\u2500\u2500\u2510  \n                       \u2502            \u2502  \n                       \u2502  Joint      \u251c\u2500 ancilla detections  \n                       \u2502 measurement \u2502  \n                       \u2502            \u2502  \n   Bell_AC\u2500\u2500\u2510          \u2514\u2500\u2500Bell_AD\u2500\u2500\u253c  \n            \u2502                      \u2502  \n           B_share                C_share  \n                                 D_share  \n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{'description': 'Chiral (2,3) quantum secret sharing A\u2192{B,C,D}',\n 'foldername': 'chiral_2_3_secret_sharing',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'ftol': 1e-06,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',                # It implements a two-outcome teleportation channel, a genuine network primitive (routing), not mere state generation.  \nStep 3: Choose (c).\nStep 4: Novelty: This is the first purely passive, post-selected, chiral teleportation router\u2014route-the-fly of a photonic qubit\u2014without active modulators or feedback, illustrating how chiral coupler constraints can be used for built-in routing.  \nStep 5: Feasibility: Pytheus can optimize two probabilistic Bell sources (H\u2013B and H\u2013C), one single-photon emitter at A, a small beamsplitter network at H combining the data photon and the two Bell halves, and two ancilla detectors whose \u201cwhich-click\u201d pattern heralds teleportation to B or C. \u201cremoved_connections\u201d enforce that no source can send photons upstream or cross-feed the wrong detector, fully within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optical, no-feedback model.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a target for Pytheus: \u201cChiral teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}.\u201d  It implements a two-outcome teleportation channel in a strictly one-way (chiral) network:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to teleport an unknown qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 at node A to either receiver B or receiver C, with the choice made passively by which heralding detector clicks at a central hub H.  No active modulators or classical feedback are used\u2014just two Bell-pair sources, a small static linear-optical circuit, and number-resolving detectors.  All photon links are enforced one way (A\u2192H\u2192B or A\u2192H\u2192C) via removed_connections.\n\nProtocol:\n1. Single-photon source at A emits the data qubit into mode A_data.  \n2. Two probabilistic Bell-pair sources:  \n   \u2022 S_HB emits one half to hub mode H_B and one half to receiver B;  \n   \u2022 S_HC emits one half to hub mode H_C and one half to receiver C.  \n3. At hub H, a three-mode linear-optical interferometer combines A_data, H_B, and H_C. No cavities, no feedback, no hyper-entanglement\u2014purely within Pytheus\u2019s abstract linear-optical toolkit.  \nStep 3: Pick (c).  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because it introduces network coding to quantum teleportation: two sender\u2013receiver pairs share a single chiral router and resource pool, yet both qubits are delivered perfectly (post-selected) with fewer Bell pairs and measurements than naive duplication.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because the entire setup can be encoded by three Bell-pair sources, one joint measurement block (modeled as a 4-photon linear-optical interferometer plus ancilla detectors), and \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to forbid any backflow or cross-coupling.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is a target for Pytheus: \u201cChiral network-coded simultaneous teleportation A,B\u2192C,D.\u201d  Two qubits at nodes A and B are teleported to nodes C and D, respectively, through a single chiral router R that performs a network-coded joint measurement\u2014reducing the usual four Bell pairs and two separate Bell-swap measurements down to three Bell pairs and one post-selected multi-photon measurement.\n\nExplanation:\nWe implement the ideal two-qubit identity channel  \n\u2003\u039b(\u03c1_A\u2297\u03c1_B) \u2192 \u03c1_C\u2297\u03c1_D  \nby quantum-network coding at a chiral router R.  Normally one would set up two independent teleporters (A\u2013R\u2013C and B\u2013R\u2013D), each consuming one Bell pair and one Bell measurement, for a total of four sources and two measurements.  Here we use instead:\n  1) Three probabilistic Bell-pair sources on directed edges A\u2192R, B\u2192R, and R\u2192D.\n  2) One direct single-photon link A\u2192C (a chiral \u201cidentity\u201d arm), so qubit A uses direct transmission instead of teleport.  \n  3) A single four-photon joint interferometric measurement at R that mixes the halves of the three Bell pairs with the B\u2192R qubit, network-coding the teleport of B to D and the identity/teleport of A to C.  \n  4) Two ancilla, number\u2010resolving detectors at R herald \u201csuccess\u201d when exactly two clicks occur in the proper ports, indicating both teleportation and identity operations succeeded.  \n  5) \u201cremoved_connections\u201d forbid any source from backflow or cross-coupling (e.g. A\u2013R source cannot feed D outputs directly), enforcing one-way (chiral) connectivity.\n\nVisualization (logical graph):\n   A_in \u2500\u2500\u2500\u25ba C_out  \n      \u2502          \n  S_AR \u2500\u25ba\u252c\u2500\u25ba measurement @ R \u2500\u25ba D_out  \n  S_BR \u2500\u25ba\u2514\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500^  \n      \u2502           (two heralding clicks)  \n      \u2514\u2500\u2500 direct  \n\nPytheus Configuration Template:\n{\n 'description': 'Chiral network-coded teleportation A,B\u2192C,D',\n 'foldername': 'chiral_netcode_teleport',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n 'edges_tried': 40,\n 'ftol': 1e-6,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',  \n 'num_anc': 2,                     # i.e. nonzero amplitudes |ab;ab> for a,b\u2208{0,1}\n   '0000','0110','1010','1111'\n ],\n 'single_emitters': [0],           # node 0 = direct A\u2192C data link\n 'amplitudes': [],\n 'tries_per_edge': 5,\n 'removed_connections': [\n   # enforce chirality: no backflow or cross-feeding from R to A or C\n   [1,3],  # S_AR\u2019s R-port (mode 1) cannot feed C_out (mode 3)\n   [2,2]   # S_BR\u2019s R-port (mode 2) cannot feed C_out (mode 2)\n ],\n 'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNode indexing guide (example):\n 0 = direct A\u2192C output (C_out)  \n 1 = R-port of Bell pair S_AR  \n 2 = R-port of Bell pair S_BR  \n 3 = D_out at node D  \n 4,5 = two heralding ancilla detectors at R  \n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Extend to k sender\u2013receiver pairs by using k+1 Bell pairs and one k+1-photon joint measurement at a chiral router.  \n \u2022 Study resource vs. success-probability scaling, chirality constraints in larger network codes, and optimization of the multi-photon measurement circuit.  \n\nThis proposal defines a new quantum-network coding primitive in quantum photonics\u2014merging chiral (directed) connectivity with resource-efficient, post-selected entanglement-swapping\u2014to deliver multiple teleportation channels through one joint router. It is a family of experiments Pytheus can optimize and ripe for a Phys.\u2009Rev.\u2009Lett. theory paper."
